text.1:
Allah opens Surah al-An'am by guiding mankind that all praise is only for Allah, the Creator of the heavens, the earth, and all that is in them, and by explaining to mankind that there is a path of darkness, which is the path followed by those who are misguided, such as considering Allah's creations as gods. Allah also shows the path of light and true guidance, which is to single out Allah and avoid attitudes and assumptions that lead to shirk, which is associating partners with Allah from His creations. But those who disbelieve in Allah prefer to choose the wrong path, which leads to shirk and darkness.

Allah praises Himself with "Alhamdulillah." Thus, the servants know how they should praise the Lord, which is by saying the phrase "Alhamdulillah." All praise is for Allah, because He is the most worthy to receive that praise, who possesses all praiseworthy attributes, and all attributes of perfection. Allah explains about Himself as the Most Praiseworthy Being by explaining that Allah is the Creator of the heavens and the earth, darkness and light. The creation of the heavens and the earth is specifically mentioned in this verse to show its special significance as a great creation of Allah, and is constantly witnessed by mankind. In both, there are lessons for mankind, all of which are signs of Allah's perfection.

The creation of darkness and light referred to in this verse is the creation of various darknesses and bright lights that are visible to the senses of sight. Both are beneficial to Allah's servants. Among the Salaf scholars, some are of the opinion that what is meant by *dhulmah* (darkness) in this verse is disbelief, and what is meant by *nur* (light) is faith; so they explain the meaning of these verses as follows: Allah created the heavens and the earth, then He showed evidence to recognize Him and single Him out. Allah warns against the path of error and shows the straight path by revealing His laws and books, even though the disbelievers act far from sound reasoning, and they always choose the path of error. Therefore, Allah says at the end of this verse, which means, "Yet those who disbelieve set up equals to their Lord." In this verse, Allah uses *dhulumat* (darknesses) in the plural form of *dhulmah* (darkness). While the word *nur* (light) is used in the singular form. The intended meaning of this difference in form is that misguidance (darkness) has many kinds, while guidance (light) is only one. The truth is only one, while falsehood is numerous. At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that the disbelievers take a contradictory attitude. They do not exclusively offer praise and worship to Allah as the Creator of the heavens and the earth and the One who created darkness and light, but they equate Allah with others in worship and praise. Even though they realize that only Allah is most worthy to receive that worship and praise.

Besides Surah al-An'am, there are four more surahs that begin with *al-hamdulillah*, meaning all praise is for Allah, namely the first surah al-Fatihah, the 18th surah al-Kahf, the 34th surah Saba', and the 35th surah Fathir. Besides giving guidance on how to properly praise Allah, we are also given guidance on how to behave and act well, which is that only Allah deserves praise, because no matter how little or how many good things we have that we can be proud of, it all comes from Allah. Allah is the Most Perfect and bestows some of His good qualities upon the creatures He wills, especially to humans. Allah truly honors this creature as mentioned in Surah al-Isra'/17 verse 70:

And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things, and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference. (al-Isra'/17: 70)

The heavens, the earth, and all that is in them, including humans, did not happen by themselves, but were created by Allah the Almighty, with perfect rules and provisions so that not a single creature can deviate from Allah's rules and provisions. If the creatures happened by themselves or according to their own will and desire, the situation would surely become chaotic, because everyone wants to be the best or better than others, and no one wants to be bad, weak, or defeated by others. But, it turns out that all of this happens because all creatures are subject to the rules and provisions of Allah the Almighty, but also the Most Wise, the Most Compassionate, and the Most Merciful.

Allah creates and provides for mankind *adz-dzulumat*, which are various darknesses, dark paths, dark atmospheres, dark lives, and so on. Allah also creates and provides for mankind *an-nur*, which is bright light, bright paths, bright lives and thoughts, transparent attitudes and behaviors. So it is up to humans to choose which one. In this verse, it is explained that many of those who deny, disbelieve, and do not have strong faith choose *dzulumat* which deviates from the fitrah and conscience of humans themselves.
text.2:
In this verse, Allah elaborates further on His creation of creatures that possess great power in their lives on this earth, namely humans. Allah created the ancestor of mankind, Adam, from a simple material, which is earth. The humans who are now large and mature also come from the essence of earth, and various food substances grown from the earth.

Then Allah determines the time of their life in the world until the time of their death arrives, and furthermore, Allah also determines the journey after death, which is the time of being resurrected from the grave on the Day of Resurrection, even though many among mankind still doubt it.

Humans who doubt their resurrection on the Day of Judgment are based on their short and simple way of thinking, which is how is it possible for humans who have died and their bodies have disintegrated into the earth, or even become substances for plants and fruits, then eaten by humans of the next generation and become flesh or strength for other humans, how can all of this be resurrected as it was when a person was still alive with a fresh and healthy body.

If their intellectual capacity cannot reach or understand Allah's power in resurrecting the dead, they should realize that their knowledge and intellectual capacity are indeed limited. We also do not know when the Day of Judgment will come. All of that is part of Allah's knowledge and power, as stated in Surah al-A'raf/7 verse 187:

"Indeed, knowledge of the Hour is with my Lord; none will reveal its time except Him." (al-A'raf/7: 187)

Allah directs His words to the polytheists who associate partners with Allah. In this verse, Allah shows again the proofs of His oneness and His power to resurrect humans on the Day of Resurrection. He is the One who created the descendants of Adam from the essence of earth. Every human occurrence certainly contains elements of earth substance.

If we pay attention to the process of human creation, it is even clearer that it originates from earth. Human creation in the womb begins with *nutfah*, which is the mixture between male sperm cells and female egg cells (ovum). Because it assimilates with food substances, the mixed *nutfah* develops into a fetus, then that state changes until it becomes a baby. Living cells are composed of various substances, and the substance itself is essentially composed of dead chemical elements such as iron and water, which come from the earth. Likewise, food substances, both from plants and from animal meat, are composed of chemical elements that come from the earth. From these food substances, sperm cells are also formed in humans or animals. Thus, with the power of Allah Almighty, dead chemical elements become living cells and eventually become humans.

Scientist's Opinion on the Creation of Man:

To date, no scientific theory can directly explain how humans were created from earth. But indirectly, some developing theories about the origin of life explain that earth plays an important role in the initial process. Most theories of the origin of life are developments of the old concept: Abiogenesis, which is defined as the descent of life from inanimate objects. Abiogenesis has long been considered the most acceptable concept for the theory of the origin of life until the law of Biogenesis (*omne vivum ex ovo* = the origin of life from other life) became more popular along with the development of modern microbiology. A deeper understanding of the concept of Abiogenesis generally examines the initial process of the formation of important chemical compounds that make up living things (amino acids, proteins, etc. up to DNA) naturally without any prior life. The most famous success is the primitive soup theory (Soup Theory) when the Urey & Miller experiment (1953) successfully synthesized organic molecules from inorganic gases (Methane, Ammonia and Hydrogen) under conditions simulated like the early state of the earth. This result was developed by Joan Oro (1961) who successfully synthesized protein from a cyanide solution. Of the several developing Abiogenesis theories, at least two of them discuss the possibility of the origin of life from earth (and rocks).

Clay theory is the theory that most closely resembles the translation of the verse above, developed by Graham Cairns "Smith (1985) since the 1960s. Clay is the mineral that forms the finest particles of earth and rock, formed as a result of rock weathering, which can also be formed from dissolved silicates. Clay minerals, like other minerals, maintain their initial formation structure during growth. The mass of certain clay minerals can influence their environment in such a way that there is a tendency for replication to occur in the subsequent formation process. Clay minerals also have a cation exchange capacity that can bind various types of elements and molecules both on their surface and within their crystal lattices. This situation allows for a natural selection process where certain molecules are captured. A sufficiently complex proto-organic molecule can be catalyzed by the surface properties of clay minerals. The final stage of this process is the formation of a new (organic) compound that is also able to reproduce itself.

Deep hot biosphere. This theory was developed by Thomas Gold in the 1990s, stating that life did not originate from the earth's surface but several kilometers below its surface. It is now known that microbial life is quite abundant up to a depth of five kilometers below the earth's surface in the form of archaea, which generally originate from the same age or even earlier than the time of the formation of bacteria. It is stated that if the origin of life is found below the surface of other planets in the solar system, it will increase the credibility of this theory.

Another developing theory is "Primitive Extraterrestrial" or exogenesis, which discusses the possibility of the origin of life from outside the earth. Recent developments, with the development of studies on DNA, more and more scientists believe that life can only occur with a brilliant design from a creator.

After presenting the scientist's opinion about the creation of humans from earth, the question arises, if Allah is able to create living cells from dead substances, why is Allah not able to resurrect humans on the Day of Resurrection? Isn't there concrete evidence in the process of human creation itself that shows Allah's power to bring about the Day of Resurrection? Allah also determines two events for humans that cannot be avoided, namely the time of their death and the time of their resurrection from the grave. No one knows the time set for death or for resurrection except Allah.

Even though the polytheists know the events of themselves clearly and the limitations of their age, all of which prove Allah's power to determine the Day of Resurrection, they still doubt it. They should be able to learn from that evidence. If Allah has the power to create dead substances into one and then give them life and determine their development, then Allah also has the power to gather back the dead substances and revive them according to His will.
text.3:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah is the One who deserves to be worshipped, who receives prayers and hopes from all His creatures in the heavens and on earth. "Allah" is the magnificent name for the Lord, Rabbal 'alamin, which was already known by the Arabs before Islam. The Arabs in the Jahiliyyah era, when asked about the God who deserves to be worshipped, would answer "Allah." The God who possesses the attributes they knew was the one they worshipped.

Another verse that aligns with the meaning of this verse is Allah's statement:

And He is God (to be worshipped) in the heaven and God (to be worshipped) on the earth, and He is the All-Wise, the All-Knowing. (az-Zukhruf/43: 84)

These two verses, namely al-An'am/6:3 and az-Zukhruf/43:84, clearly glorify Allah because of His power to revive the dead, and especially because of His uniqueness in knowing the Day of Resurrection and His oneness in divinity and the oneness of His essence that is worshipped in the heavens and on earth. To Allah alone are directed the prayers of all creatures in this universe.

Then Allah affirms that He knows everything they conceal or reveal, both their words and deeds, as well as everything that occurs in their hearts. Everything that humans strive for does not escape God's knowledge. Good deeds will be rewarded, and bad deeds will be punished. God's attention to human actions is perfect because all actions will receive recompense from Him.
text.4:
Allah explains the attitude of the polytheists who are completely unable to respond to and contemplate the proofs of truth in the verses of the Qur'an, which explain the proofs of Allah's Oneness, the Day of Resurrection, and the vastness of His knowledge. They do not even contemplate and do not seek guidance from the natural signs they witness on the surface of the earth or within themselves. All the *ayat kauniyah* and the verses that affirm the prophethood of Muhammad, they all abandon and deny. Yet, it is these verses that show the existence of the One God who controls and manages the universe, and there is no god worthy of worship except Allah.

If they did not turn away from the verses of Allah due to stubbornness or fanaticism towards their leaders, the truth would certainly be apparent to them, and they would not oppose the teachings of the Messenger of Allah (saw).

In accordance with this verse, Allah says in Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 2-3:

"Whenever there comes to them a new reminder from their Lord, they listen to it while they are at play. Their hearts are heedless." (al-Anbiya'/21: 2-3)
text.5:
Allah explains that the reason the polytheists always turn away from Allah's verses is because they have denied the truth when the truth came to them. This evil of theirs is a result of them closing the path to acquiring knowledge.

What is meant by "the truth" is the religion of Allah brought by Prophet Muhammad, which contains religious principles, laws of Sharia, worship, transactions, the forbidden and the permissible, morals, and so on, all of which are explained in the Al-Qur'an. Their denial of religion means denying the Al-Qur'an as the foundation of religion. If they understood the Al-Qur'an and reflected upon it, they certainly would not deny the teachings of that religion.

Allah affirms that the truth of the news they always mocked in the world will be proven to them. At one point, they experienced humiliation in this world and destruction in the hereafter as a result of their denial of religion. Conversely, they witnessed the victory of the Muslims. Allah's warning to them was previously considered insignificant. Likewise, Allah's promise of victory for the Muslims, which later proved to be true, including the arrival of a drought that befell them, and the destruction of the polytheists in the Battle of Badr and other battles, as well as the victory of the Muslims with the liberation of the city of Mecca (Fath Makkah).

In the Al-Qur'an, the mockery of the polytheists towards the prophets and the religion of Allah is repeatedly narrated, and this mockery is in stages. First, they do not pay attention to Allah's verses and natural signs and do not want to reflect on them. Second, they deny them. This second attitude exceeds the first level, because people who are indifferent do not necessarily deny. Third, they ridicule them. A person who denies does not necessarily reach the point of ridiculing. This attitude of ridicule has reached the peak of denial. The disbelievers go through all three stages.
text.6:
Allah warns that indeed the disbelievers already know how many generations from previous nations Allah has destroyed, such as the people of Noah, 'Ad, Thamud, and others. They belonged to generations of people who had been given strength, steadfastness, and freedom on earth that Allah had never given to the polytheistic Arabs. Their land was constantly showered with heavy rainfall, bringing prosperity and fertility. Rivers flowed, irrigating their gardens and plantations, adding to the beauty and prosperity of their land. All the blessings and favors that Allah bestowed upon previous nations did not prevent His punishment because of the sins they committed.

Two kinds of sins they committed led to their destruction: First, the sin of opposing the messengers and denying their teachings, as well as mocking them; and second, the sin of ingratitude, that is, an attitude of denial towards the various blessings that Allah had given them. They even used those blessings for things that were contrary to Allah's guidance.

Many verses of the Qur'an tell about the causes of their destruction. For example, the word of Allah:

"And never did We destroy the cities except while their people were wrongdoers." (al-Qasas/28: 59)

The punishment of the Lord inflicted upon the disbelieving people is of two kinds:

First, punishment by completely destroying them until they are annihilated. Second, punishment by eliminating the freedom and strength of that people so that they become a weak and humiliated people.

When they are annihilated, then others who possess good qualities, contrary to the qualities of the annihilated people, will emerge to replace them.

This verse warns the polytheists of Mecca that their strength and power cannot prevent Allah's punishment, just as it has been inflicted upon previous nations.
text.7:
This verse explains the doubts of the disbelievers who deny the truth of revelation and the prophethood of Muhammad. Prophet Muhammad already knew, based on the explanations of previous verses, that the reason they rejected the religion was their turning away from the verses of the Qur'an and the closing of their hearts to contemplate and reflect on the events in this universe. Many proofs of the Oneness of Allah are visible in humans themselves and on this earth, both *ayat kauniyah* (signs of the universe) and verses that speak of the universe, which are very clear; nothing is obscure or vague. Nevertheless, the polytheists remain in disbelief. The Qur'an's explanations of the proofs of Allah's Oneness in this universe do not change their stance.

Even if the revelation sent down to Prophet Muhammad had been printed on paper and they could witness it with their own eyes and hold it with their own hands, the disbelievers would still say: "This is nothing but clear magic." Such words are driven by extraordinary arrogance and deep hostility. They continue to view divine revelation as magic, and feel that they themselves are bewitched.
text.8:
This verse explains the beliefs of the Meccan disbelievers regarding prophethood. They thought that an angel should accompany Muhammad, giving warnings with him and strengthening his prophethood, or that Allah should send down an angel as a messenger. They even desired to see God (al-Furqan/25: 7 and 21).

Among the Arabs, there was a belief about the relationship between Allah and His creation. According to them, the one who should be the intermediary (messenger) must be a spiritual being (angel). A human, even if he possesses high spiritual perfection, such as intellect, morals, and noble manners, could not possibly be a messenger, because he still associates with humans and still has physical needs, such as eating, drinking, and striving. This kind of belief phenomenon was not new in the time of the Prophet Muhammad, but had existed since the time of the Prophet Hud (al-Mu'minun/23: 33-34).

The Meccan polytheists had two assumptions regarding the position of angels in prophethood. The first assumption was that the angel himself was the messenger. The second assumption was that the angel accompanied the Prophet and explained directly to them that Muhammad was a Prophet. This second assumption of theirs, if not linked to the direct presence of the angel before them, would not be a source of dispute, because Muhammad had already explained to them that they were always visited by angels. But they considered themselves equal to the Prophet in human characteristics. Therefore, they thought they were also capable of facing angels and receiving lessons directly from angels. This is where the great error of the disbelievers lies, regarding themselves; they reject everything they do not obtain directly.

Regarding their second assumption, Allah explains in this verse that if Allah were to present the angels before them in their original form, it would certainly lead to their destruction, and they would not be given the opportunity to declare faith, and even punishment would immediately befall them. Their destruction could be caused by the awesomeness of the angel's form when the angel appeared to them, or they would be destroyed by the angel because they denied the verses of Allah.
text.9: This verse clarifies the assumption of the polytheists of Mecca regarding the apostleship of angels, as mentioned in the tafsir of Surah al-An'am/6 verse 8. If Allah had made messengers from the ranks of angels, as the polytheists of Mecca believed, then Allah would have certainly made those angels like human males. But if the angel who became the Messenger (Prophet) were to disguise himself in human form, then they would surely say he was a human. Because they would not see the angel except in a form with human characteristics. At that time, doubts and hesitations would arise in their souls, and they would certainly deny the angels who disguised themselves as humans, just as they denied the Prophet Muhammad. They would state their opinion that the messenger must be an angel. Whereas they do not know what the original form of the angel is like. Thus, they spin around in a circle of uncertainty with no clear beginning or end. The polytheists of Mecca are an example of most people who fall into difficulty because of their mistakes in choosing a way of life, and ultimately they are confused in seeking a way out.
text.10:
After Allah explained the confusion in the minds of the disbelievers regarding prophethood, where they continuously denied it, this verse clarifies that their resistance to the prophethood of Muhammad is similar to the resistance of disbelievers to Allah's messengers in the past. The hostility and insults experienced by the Prophet Muhammad were also experienced by the messengers before him. Allah says:

"Alangkah besar penyesalan terhadap hamba-hamba itu, setiap datang seorang rasul kepada mereka, mereka selalu memperolok-olokkannya." (Yasin/36: 30) - "Alas for the servants! There does not come to them any messenger but they ridicule him." (Yasin/36:30)

The insults of the Quraysh disbelievers towards the Prophet Muhammad are a continuation of humanity's hostility towards the messengers since ancient times, so the consequences they face will certainly be the same as the consequences faced by previous peoples. This verse explains that those who mock and insult the messengers will be afflicted with torment.

This verse explains the *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way) that applied to humanity in the past with Allah's messengers. This verse also serves as a comforter and solace to the Prophet Muhammad, because of the insults of his people towards him, namely the news of the ultimate victory for the Prophet and his followers, and the defeat of his enemies. However, the people of the Prophet Muhammad will not receive punishment like the previous peoples, namely destruction and annihilation of life. The punishment inflicted upon them will not result in destruction and annihilation because the Prophet Muhammad is "Nabiyyurrahmah," the prophet who brings mercy to mankind.
text.11:
After explaining the destruction of several peoples who opposed the messengers in the past, Allah, in this verse, commands Prophet Muhammad to tell his people to travel the earth and visit the places where those who denied the prophets were destroyed. This is because, through this travel, they can witness historical sites for themselves, so they can reflect on why those past nations were destroyed, even though they were powerful and mighty. After that, they should look at themselves and compare themselves to those extinct communities.

The disbelievers of Mecca were actually travelers because they generally lived as traders between regions in the Arabian Peninsula. But in their travels as traders, they did not pay attention to the remnants of extinct communities, such as the people of Noah and Thamud in Northern Arabia and the people of 'Ad in Southern Arabia. How many generations have been destroyed and then replaced with new generations, as Allah explained in verse six of this surah. All of this should be used as material for studying the history of the nation itself, even if it takes a long time, because many beneficial lessons for future generations can be learned from the historical experiences of past nations.

With the revelation of this verse, the heart of Prophet Muhammad felt comforted, because it contained an indication that the polytheists would experience defeat.
text.12:
Allah commands His Messenger to ask his disbelieving people, who owns everything in the heavens and the earth? This question is to refute the basis of beliefs that associate partners with Allah (shirk), because the Jahiliyyah Arabs actually acknowledged that the Creator of the heavens and the earth is "Allah" (al-'Ankabut/29:61 and Luqman/31: 25).

Then Allah commands the Messenger to give the answer, that "everything belongs to Allah." The polytheists would certainly answer that question with a similar answer. There is no other answer for them; and they will not deny it, because they should not attribute anything from this universe to anyone other than Allah. Only Allah is the King and Owner of this universe with all its contents.

Allah, who is acknowledged by the polytheists as the Creator who created the heavens and the earth and who owns both, has introduced Himself through His Messenger that the attribute of compassion is a necessity of His essence, that compassion encompasses all of His creation. He is the Most Merciful to all of His servants by bestowing various kinds of physical and spiritual blessings upon them. If they commit sins, He does not immediately inflict punishment upon them, instead they are given the opportunity to repent and return to the path of Allah. The sins they commit that result in Allah's wrath are the result of human error itself. Is it not because of Allah's compassion that humans were created in a state of perfect fitrah? Then they are given the opportunity to recognize and acknowledge His Oneness by showing evidence that exists within humans and in the universe. Because of Allah's mercy, messengers were sent to them carrying Books full of teachings that lead to His pleasure and that prevent them from His wrath. But then it is humans who tarnish these good teachings with the various evils they commit. They deny the verses of Allah and insult the messengers. Allah says:

And We did not wrong them, but they were the ones who wronged themselves. (az-Zukhruf/43:76)

It is also because of Allah's mercy that the polytheists of Mecca were not destroyed like previous nations. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

Indeed, when Allah finished creating this creation, Allah wrote a Book that is with Him above the 'Arsh, "Indeed, My mercy precedes My wrath." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Based on that compassion, Allah will gather all of mankind on the Day of Resurrection, about which there is no doubt. Justice will be established on that day. No one will escape or be forgotten. It is a great mercy for human life and existence, if everyone is certain and aware of the occurrence of that Day of Gathering. This awareness becomes an impetus for him to purify his soul and elevate his character. The injustice that occurs in worldly life will certainly be reckoned by Allah with full justice on the Day of Resurrection.

Those who harm themselves, namely those who tarnish the pure fitrah of their creation, damage their healthy mentality and eliminate their willingness to accept the prophethood of Muhammad and refuse to listen to the revelation, and they choose the path of disbelief, because they do not believe in the Hereafter, they are the losers.
text.13:
This verse states that the universe with all its contents belongs to Allah, and everything that happens at night and during the day also belongs to Allah. No matter how small an object is, occupying any corner in the space of this universe, it must be under the power of Allah. It is impossible for it to move or remain still in any space and time without the power and will of Allah, because it belongs to Him. His control is absolute over Allah.

Then it is emphasized that Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing. The range of His hearing encompasses this universe. Even the sound of an ant's footsteps on a smooth rock will certainly not escape His hearing and knowledge.
text.14:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger again to ask the polytheists, "Should I take as a protector other than Allah, who could give me help in times of difficulty or ward off disaster from me?" Of course, the Messenger would not act like the polytheists and the People of the Book of old. They made their idols and their priests as protectors, who, according to their i'tiqad (belief), could give them happiness or ward off misery from them.

There is no true protector or helper except Allah, who created the heavens and the earth. Allah mentions His attribute as the Creator to affirm the rejection of the idea of placing anyone other than Allah as a helper; because only Allah is worthy of being asked for help. It is not fitting to make anyone other than Him an intermediary who can influence the Divine will. Only to the Creator of the heavens and the earth are prayers and hopes directed. His will cannot be influenced by anyone. He is the Lord who provides sustenance, food and drink, and all benefits to mankind. Conversely, He does not need food, drink, or sustenance; rather, He is Pure from all needs for food, drink, and so on, and He does not need anyone else. Allah says:

"I do not want from them any provision, nor do I want them to feed Me." (adz-dzariyat/51: 57)

Furthermore, the Messenger of Allah (saw) is commanded to convey to the disbelievers that he is commanded by Allah to be the first to submit to Him, to uphold His commands, not to supplicate to anyone other than Him, and to continue to establish the religion in the midst of his ummah. The Messenger Muhammad is also forbidden from being a polytheist, that is, one who worships other than Allah and considers other than Allah as a helper or intermediary to draw closer to Him.
text.15: After Allah explained the foundation of religion that a Messenger must adhere to, in this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to declare to the polytheists that if he were to commit disobedience, violate Allah's commands, or deviate from the religious principles established by Allah, then the Messenger would fear the torment of the Day of Judgment befalling him. This is because on that day, Allah will confront His servants to inflict torment upon those who are sinful and grant rewards to those who perform righteous deeds. On that terrible day, no one will be able to help another, neither out of affection nor brotherhood. This verse demonstrates the character of the Messenger of Allah, that even though he was far from the possibility of committing sin, his heart remained fearful of Allah in all circumstances.
text.16:
Allah explains in this verse that those who are spared from punishment on the Day of Judgment are those who receive mercy from Allah. Because Allah frees them from the distress of that terrible day and grants them blessings and admits them into Paradise. The person who is kept away from punishment obtains two happinesses: the happiness of being free from punishment and the happiness of receiving mercy; this happiness is a great triumph.

The happiness that Allah gives on the Day of Judgment is truly a mercy of Allah's compassion for His servants and is not at all an obligation for God; because there is no power above His power. But the attribute of mercy itself is a necessity for God, because that attribute is one of His attributes of perfection, and the necessity of the attribute of mercy for Allah is stated by Allah in the Qur'an as mentioned in this surah (al-Ma'idah/5) verses 12 and 54.
text.17:
In this verse, Allah's omnipotence is reaffirmed, stating that no one can remove a harm that Allah inflicts upon a person except Allah Himself, such as sickness, poverty, grief, humiliation, and so on, which cause suffering to humans both outwardly and inwardly. It is not idols, shamans, or other protectors besides Allah, which are often regarded by polytheists, that can remove such harm. Likewise, no one can prevent a good that Allah bestows upon a person, such as wealth, health, glory, strength, and so on, which bring happiness both outwardly and inwardly. Allah is All-Powerful to preserve all good so that a person remains as He wills.

After completing the five daily prayers, the Prophet Muhammad always recited a prayer, among others:

"O Allah, there is none who can withhold what You give, and there is none who can give what You withhold, and the glory of a person does not benefit him against Your punishment." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from al-Warrad)

This verse also indicates that every human being, whether desiring good or avoiding harm, must seek help from Allah alone by striving according to His Sunnah that applies in this universe and by offering prayers fully to Him.

Allah's word:

"And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you." (Gafir/40: 60)
text.18:
This verse affirms the perfection of Allah's absolute sovereignty over His servants. He is the Supreme Ruler over His servants, managing and regulating all their matters and affairs according to His will. No one can plead to be able to escape from His dominion.

The perfection of Allah's power and sovereignty over His servants is accompanied by the perfection of His wisdom in managing the needs of His servants and the vastness of His knowledge of all matters, small and hidden. He is the All-Knowing of what is beneficial and what is harmful to His servants. There is no matter that He does not know the end of. His management of His servants is directed towards a goal, namely the perfection of humanity.

He is Allah, the Almighty and the One, there is no partner for Him. Therefore, it is not fitting to worship anything other than Him.

Allah says:

"So do not invoke anyone along with Allah." (al-Jinn/72: 18)
text.19:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger again to ask the disbelievers of Quraysh about the *syahadah* (testimony of proof) that is stronger, namely testimony that cannot contain elements of falsehood, fabrication, or error.

*Syahadah* is information that originates from knowledge, recognition, and conviction based on sensory absorption or mental and emotional responses. What matter is to be testified to? And who will be the witness, so that the testimony is not doubted?

The matter requested to be testified to is the prophethood of Muhammad and the oneness of Allah that he taught. The disbelievers rejected it. To address this, Allah asks the Messenger to ask, what is the greatest testimony? Prophet Muhammad is asked to answer that the greatest testimony is the testimony from Allah that the Prophet has believed while the disbelievers of Quraysh have disbelieved. Also, that they are then asked for their testimony, whether it is true that there are gods besides Allah. Prophet Muhammad is asked to state that he has never witnessed this. What he witnessed is only that God is One, and he is not responsible for their testimony. Allah has revealed the Al-Qur'an to him to warn about the punishment for those who deny his prophethood and the teachings he brought, which have been strengthened by Allah's testimony. Likewise, the Al-Qur'an was revealed to give a warning to all those to whom the Al-Qur'an has reached. It is obligatory upon them to follow the Al-Qur'an until the Day of Judgment.

Allah's testimony to the prophethood of Muhammad is:

First: The Book of Al-Qur'an as an eternal miracle. Humans are unable to imitate it, either in terms of language or meaning, and its contents containing news of the unseen, promises of victory for the Messenger and his people over the polytheists. In the Al-Qur'an itself, there are many questions from Allah about the prophethood and messengership of Muhammad.

Second: Heavenly books such as the Torah and the Gospel that describe the birth of Prophet Muhammad as well as his characteristics and signs of prophethood.

As for Allah's testimony to His oneness and His omnipotence to establish the Day of Resurrection, in addition to the testimony of His Book, is:

First: The creation of humans and the universe, which contains many proofs of His oneness and the perfection of His attributes.

Second: The nature of human nature which tends to believe in the oneness of God with His perfect attributes.

Then Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah to say to the polytheists that they actually acknowledge the existence of other gods besides Allah and that he would not acknowledge it as they do. In fact, he was commanded to say that indeed God is Allah, the One and Only, as a statement of belief that is completely contrary to the beliefs of the polytheists and that he is free from the effort to deify what they consider to be partners of Allah such as statues, idols or other names that are synonymous with the meaning of partner.
text.20:
This verse adds further explanation regarding the truth of Prophet Muhammad's prophethood, namely the explanation that the People of the Book, from Jews and Christians, actually know that the last prophet sent by Allah is Prophet Muhammad because the signs of his prophethood are very clearly stated in their holy books.

It is narrated that the disbelievers of Mecca went to Medina to ask the Jews and Christians about the characteristics of Muhammad. But they denied that there was news about Muhammad's prophethood in the Torah and the Gospel. This news was so clear that they knew it as clearly as they knew their own children.

Allah states that they have harmed themselves because they do not believe in Muhammad's prophethood, even denying it with hostility. Therefore, they deny what they know. The denial of the Jewish priests is for the same reason as the denial of the polytheists of Mecca.

The Jewish priests did not want to believe in Muhammad because they were afraid of losing their dignity and position among their religious followers. In the view of Islam, all people are equal in status. There is no difference between priests and the people. If they commit the same mistake, the punishment will be the same, there is no difference between scholars and the general public.

Likewise, the leaders of the Quraysh did not want to believe in Prophet Muhammad because they were afraid of losing their dignity and position. If they embraced Islam, they would sit side by side with the common people and the poor, such as Bilal from Ethiopia (Habasyah) and others. They themselves are the ones who harm themselves. Their loss is due to the weakness of their ideals and will, and the loss of sound reasoning, so that they deny the knowledge they possess.
text.21:
This verse affirms that there is no one more at a loss than those who fabricate lies against Allah, such as saying that Allah has a child, has partners, or making something other than Allah the basis of prayer and worship, making it a protector, intercessor, and so on, and adding to religious teachings that have no basis.

Likewise, they are very unjust, denying the verses of the Qur'an, distorting the contents of the Torah and the Gospel, and rejecting the miracles of the Messenger, which they call magic, as well as denying the *ayat kauniyah* (signs of the universe) that demonstrate the oneness of Allah. Indeed, those who commit injustice, namely fabricating lies against Allah or denying His verses, especially denying both, will not attain success on the Day of Judgment. They will receive punishment from Allah. In this world, they will not be victorious either, because they were defeated by the Muslims, as in the Battle of Badr.
text.22:
In this verse, Allah warns the polytheists about the Day of Resurrection, when all of humanity will be gathered. On that day, people will only be divided into two groups: those who are losers and those who are fortunate. Then Allah says to the polytheists, "Where are your deities that you used to claim were partners with Allah?" Allah asks this because, in the world, they used to seek help and offer prayers to deities other than Allah, whom they made as protectors or intermediaries to draw closer to Allah or to intercede for them on the Day of Judgment. Why have those deities disappeared and are not seen with them on that day? As Allah states:

"And We do not see with you your 'partners' which you claimed [to be associated with Allah]. It has certainly been severed between you, and lost from you is what you used to claim." (al-An'am/6: 94)
text.23:
Then Allah explains in this verse that when they could not provide an answer to justify their polytheism while in the world, they then answered with an oath that they were not those who associated partners with Allah. Such is the end of all their disbelief and polytheism. While in the world, they adhered to the religion of their ancestors. For those objects of worship and adoration, they were willing to die in battle. But in the end, they absolve themselves of that polytheism and disbelief. Swearing an oath, they deny their own objects of worship. They thought that their statement would be of benefit to them, but on the contrary, it only added a new sin for them.

Their actions and deeds become witnesses to their polytheism. Their feet and hands will recount all their sins. Therefore, in the end, they will confess their disbelief.

Allah says:

"Our Lord, these are our partners whom we used to invoke besides You." (an-Nahl/16: 86)
text.24:
After Allah recounts the statements of the polytheists on the Day of Judgment who attempt to absolve themselves of polytheism, in this verse, Allah commands the Messenger and his followers to observe the astonishing attitude of these polytheists. How can it be that they lie before the Lord who knows all that is unseen, who needs no testimony? There is a strangeness and oddity worthy of attention: that everything they considered partners with Allah turned out to be of no benefit to them whatsoever. The intercession, help, blessings, protection, and so on that they expected from those partners vanished without a trace.

Allah says:

"They (the angels) will say, "Where are those you used to invoke besides Allah?" They will say, "They have vanished from us." (al-A'raf/7: 37)
text.25:
Regarding the reason for the revelation of this verse, Ibn 'Abbas said: At one time, Abu Sufyan bin Harb, Walid bin Mugirah, Nadhar bin al-Harith, 'Utbah and Syaibah, both sons of Rabi'ah, Umayyah and Ubay, both sons of Khalaf, listened to what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) conveyed. They asked Nadhar, "O Aba Qutailah, what did Muhammad say?" He replied, "I don't know what he said, but indeed I saw him moving his lips talking about something, and what he said was just lies like those done by people of the past, like what I have told you about the past." Nadhar was a person who talked a lot about the past, and he spoke to the Quraysh and they enjoyed what he said. Then Allah revealed this verse.

This verse explains the factors that caused them not to believe. A group of disbelievers listened to the recitation of the verses of the Qur'an which invited them to monotheism. But the sound of the verses could not influence their stance, so they remained in disbelief. They could not understand and comprehend this verse of Allah because there was a veil covering their hearts. They could not hear the verses of Allah well as if there was something in their ears that disturbed their hearing so that the verses of Allah did not touch their souls.

The veil over their hearts and the blockage in their hearing are actually a depiction of intense fanaticism or blind imitation on their own part, then Allah made it an obstacle for them to contemplate and study these realities. Because of this blind imitation, they could not distinguish between what is right and what is wrong, they were unwilling to consider between the understanding they adhered to and the understanding of others, between their religion and other religions.

Every belief that differed from what they believed was rejected without thinking about which was closer to the truth, and which brought more guidance to the path of happiness in this world and the hereafter. Whenever they saw signs or evidence that showed the truth of Muhammad's prophethood, they did not believe it, even accusing him of sorcery because of intense fanaticism and driven by a deep sense of hostility. They could no longer respond to the meaning of the verses of the Qur'an and their response was limited to the literal words of the verses.

Their hearts were so empty in responding to these verses that when they came to the Prophet Muhammad to refute his da'wah, they said that the verses of the Qur'an were nothing but tales of people of the past. Whereas in the Qur'an there are many reports about the unseen, laws, moral teachings, knowledge and so on which until the end of time still have high value. But all of this was seen by the polytheists as the same as the myths and superstitions of people of the past which did not provide guidance for human life. This shows the darkness of their hearts and minds. If they had only reflected on the stories in the Qur'an which explain the lessons of human history, the law of cause and effect that applied to past peoples, they would not have said such things.
text.26:
This verse explains that they did not stop at denying the verses of the Qur'an and viewing them as magic. They even prevented others from listening and inciting them, so that those people would not be attracted to the Qur'an, which has beautiful language and dense meaning that surpasses the language of their poets. The leaders of the polytheistic community felt worried about the influence of the Qur'an's style on its listeners. They realized that the opportunity to pay attention to the verses of the Qur'an meant an opportunity to respond to its miracle; that is why they hindered others.

Besides preventing others, they themselves distanced themselves from the Qur'an, to show that they strongly opposed it and to strengthen their prohibition.

Even though the polytheists had made various efforts to extinguish the light of Islam, they would not succeed. In fact, Allah states at the end of this verse that their actions were not destroying Islam but destroying themselves without them realizing it. The warning of their destruction was proven true a few years later in various battles and victories on the side of the Messenger of Allah.
text.27:
This verse explains their state on the Day of Judgment, which will be witnessed by all of humanity. When they are brought before the fire of Hell, only then will they realize the punishment they will receive, and regret will arise within them for their disbelief and insolence towards Allah and His Messenger during their lives in the world. At that terrifying and dreadful moment, they will submit a request to Allah to be returned to the world to repent, perform righteous deeds, and believe in Allah and His Messenger, no longer denying the verses of Allah, and they will promise to become believers.

Their desire to return to the world demonstrates their ignorance, because it is an impossible thing. Those polytheists, in front of the fire of Hell, lament their fate due to their actions in the world, being followers of idolatry and simply agreeing with what their leaders said. But that lamentation is of no use. Allah says:

And those who were followed will say, "If only we had another chance, we would disown them as they have disowned us." Thus will Allah show them their deeds as regrets for them. And they will never escape the Fire. (al-Baqarah/2: 167)
text.28:
This verse affirms that all the disobedience they concealed during their time in the world becomes clearly visible to them at that time. Their desire to return to the world to become believers is not genuine, but rather stems from something else: after the bad consequences of their disbelief and polytheism become apparent to them, and they see the torment of hell that will befall them. They feel afraid and want to escape that torment by being returned to the world. On the Day of Judgment, nothing can be hidden. All realities will be revealed, even the limbs of humans will testify to all their bad and good deeds. Thus, how can anything be hidden from Allah, the All-Knowing of the outward and the inward?

Allah says:

"On that Day you will be exhibited (before your Lord), not a secret of yours will be hidden." (al-Haqqah/69: 18)

If they were returned to the world as they wished, they would surely revert to their former ways, that is, return to polytheism, hypocrisy, deceit, disobedience, and everything forbidden, because evil is ingrained in them and due to their weakness in accepting anything good. Their desire to become believers and not deny the verses of Allah is nothing but a lie, because that statement is born out of fear of the torment of hell, and their nature will not change. If they returned to the world, they would return arrogant, boastful, and committing sins.
text.29:
If they were returned to the world, they would say that truly there is no other life except the life experienced in this world. According to the understanding of the disbelievers, life is limited to worldly life alone. They deny the existence of the Day of Resurrection, the Day of Recompense or Reckoning. Likewise, there is no reward or punishment in the afterlife. Therefore, they act in this world based on their individual desires and interests.

Allah says:

And they say, "There is not for us except our worldly life; we die and live, and nothing destroys us except time." And they have of that no knowledge; they are only assuming. (al-Jatsiyah/45: 24)
text.30:
After Allah explained the denial of the disbelievers regarding the Day of Judgment while they were alive in the world, in this verse, Allah explains their situation in the Hereafter when the error of their views is revealed. In a very emotionally stirring atmosphere, when the disbelievers are ordered to stand in a designated place before Allah's court, Allah asks them, "Is this not the truth?"

Is not the Day of Judgment that they are experiencing now, which they used to doubt and even mock, a reality? It is not a false report as they said. Faced with this question from Allah, they cannot call upon the partners they worshipped, they cannot help each other, so in the end they answer Allah's question, "Yes, by our Lord." They can no longer deny the reality of the Day of Resurrection, and they strengthen their acknowledgment of the truth by using the oath "by our Lord." They admit that they have been misguided and disbelieving all this time.

In accordance with that confession, they receive punishment on the Day of Judgment which they always denied during their lives. The disbelief that they emphasized and relied on is the cause of all the suffering they experience.
text.31:
This verse explains the loss of the disbelievers who deny the oneness of Allah, the prophethood of Muhammad, and the Day of Resurrection. They deny the meeting with Allah. They do not obtain benefits like the believers do. The benefits of the believers in this world, as a result of their faith, include inner satisfaction, pleasure, tranquility, and feeling happy with Allah's blessings in all circumstances, they are grateful to Him for all blessings, patient and steadfast in suffering. As for the benefits in the Hereafter as a result of their faith, such as obtaining divine pleasure, experiencing ease in the reckoning (hisab), and the indescribable happiness of Paradise.

The disbelievers who deny the meeting with Allah lose all these benefits. They are the ones who do not believe in the Day of Resurrection; life for them is limited to this world only; therefore, their lives are always chased by limitless desires and their conflicting interests. They never experience inner satisfaction, spiritual peace, and divine pleasure; in fact, they are closer to Satan who makes them lose their bearings. Such is the state of the disbelievers until the Day of Judgment. The Day of Judgment will come suddenly, no one can know it. On the Day of Judgment, the disbelievers express their regret because they limited this life to worldly life only, so they neglected to prepare themselves for the Day of Judgment. They bear a heavy burden, namely their sins and mistakes, and they will receive punishment for those sins and mistakes. The heavy burden they bear on the Day of Judgment is truly a very evil burden.
text.32:
This verse affirms the depiction of worldly and afterlife life. The life of this world is truly nothing but play and amusement. For those who deny the Day of Resurrection, so they deeply love worldly life, like children playing, they obtain pleasure and satisfaction during that play. The more skillful they are in using their playing time, the more pleasure and satisfaction they obtain. After playing, they gain nothing. Or like a drug addict, he gets a very pleasant feeling when he is immersed in the intoxication of narcotics. All unpleasant thoughts disappear, fatigue and spiritual and physical lethargy vanish at that time. But it is only for a short time, when the effect of the narcotics is gone, that pleasant feeling disappears and he suffers from fatigue heavier than before using narcotics. Such is the condition of those who deny the Day of Resurrection and life after death. They limit themselves to that short opportunity. Life for them is play and amusement.

Believers and those who are God-fearing do not think like those who disbelieve. It is not appropriate for them to limit themselves to the line of worldly life. What is the meaning of pleasure and enjoyment that is only temporary, to then suffer without gaining anything? Therefore, believers should choose eternal life, namely the life of the hereafter, because that is the best life. To face this long life, one should prepare oneself with good deeds and obedience to Allah. The life of this world is only a means to the life of the hereafter. Believers prefer eternal life to temporary life.
text.33:
Allah states that He knows that the words of the polytheists of Mecca sadden the heart of the Prophet Muhammad, such as when they say: Muhammad is a liar, a magician, a poet, a soothsayer, and so on, and they try to distance Muhammad from his people. It should be known that this action is carried out not only because of their denial, but because they are unjust people who disobey Allah. The emergence of this sadness is natural for the Prophet, because his pure and holy soul and mind cannot bear to see the error and evil that exists in his people, even though he always invites and calls them to the right path.

Allah forbids the Prophet Muhammad from being saddened by the actions of the disbelievers because the prophets before him also experienced the same thing. This prohibition is also mentioned in Allah's word:

And let not their speech grieve you. Indeed, all power belongs to Allah. He is the Hearing, the Knowing. (Yunus/10: 65)

Allah's word:

So let not their speech grieve you. Indeed, We know what they conceal and what they declare. (Yasin/36: 76)

Allah forbids the Prophet Muhammad from being saddened because they do not believe, in Allah's word:

And be patient, [O Muhammad], and your patience is not but through Allah. And do not grieve over them and do not be in distress from what they conspire. (an-Nahl/16: 127)

Allah's word:

And do not grieve over them or be in distress from their plot. (an-Naml/27: 70)

The disbelievers of Mecca did not disbelieve in the Prophet Muhammad. For example, they once entrusted him with the task of resolving a dispute that was very dangerous to their unity, such as the matter of placing the Hajar Aswad (black stone) back in its place in the Kaaba, and so on.

But they did not believe in the prophethood of Muhammad, the verses of the Al-Qur'an that Allah revealed, the existence of the Day of Judgment, the Day of Resurrection, and everything that Muhammad brought and conveyed.

Ar-Razi in his tafsir explains four kinds of denial by the disbelievers of Mecca, namely:

1.  Their hearts acknowledge Muhammad as a trustworthy person, but their mouths deny him, because they deny the Al-Qur'an and the prophethood of Muhammad.

2.  They did not want to state that Muhammad was a liar, because they knew very well the true state of Muhammad, who never lied. According to them, Muhammad himself imagined in his mind that Allah had appointed him as a Prophet and Messenger, and then he called people.

3.  They always denied prophethood and the message, even though miracles and strong arguments had been presented, they still denied the verses of Allah, but towards the person of Muhammad, they did not deny him.

4.  They did not want to believe in miracles and arguments, in fact they said that the miracles were mere magic.

From the structure of the wording of this verse, it is understood that Allah elevates the degree of the Prophet Muhammad. That degree will not decrease even if the disbelievers of Mecca deny and reject it. The height of that degree is understood from the word of Allah swt, which mentions that the command to follow Muhammad is mentioned after the command to follow Allah.

Allah says:

He who obeys the Messenger has obeyed Allah; but those who turn away - We have not sent you over them as a guardian. (an-Nisa'/4: 80)

Allah's word:

Indeed, those who give you allegiance, [O Muhammad] - they are only giving allegiance to Allah. (al-Fath/48: 10)
text.34:
Allah reminds Prophet Muhammad not to be saddened and grieved by the actions of the disbelievers, because such things are common; the prophets and messengers whom Allah had sent before were also denied and rejected, even harmed, and their followers were persecuted. But they remained steadfast and patient in the face of such things.

Allah swt says:

And if they deny you (Muhammad), so did the people before them deny [their messengers] - the people of Noah and 'Aad and Thamud. (al-Hajj/22: 42)

Allah swt says:

And if they deny you, [O Muhammad] - then already were messengers denied before you. And to Allah are returned [all] matters. (Fathir/35: 4)

From the verse that means (until Our help came to them), it is understood that the previous prophets and messengers were very steadfast and patient in facing all kinds of actions from their people, no matter what happened. Because of such actions, Allah inflicted great calamities upon them, such as lightning strikes, violent earthquakes, storms, and so on. Allah saved the prophets and messengers along with their believing people from great torment and saved them from the actions of their disbelieving people.

This verse is a consolation for Prophet Muhammad in facing the treatment and actions of the polytheists of Mecca, because just as the previous prophets and messengers were saved by Allah, He will surely save Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims, and make Islam victorious.

This consolation is further explained emphatically in another verse of Allah swt:

So be patient, [O Muhammad], as were those of determination among the messengers and do not be impatient for them. On the Day they see that which they are promised, [it will be] as though they had not remained [in the world] except an hour of a day. [This is] notification. And will [anyone] be destroyed except the defiantly disobedient people? (al-Ahqaf/46: 35)

Allah swt says:

And be patient over what they say and avoid them with gracious avoidance. (al-Muzzammil/73: 10)

Allah also affirms that Allah's help and promise that has been established will not change in the slightest, neither the words of the promise itself nor the meaning and content of the promise.

This verse also alludes to Prophet Muhammad that the story related to the attitudes and actions of the people of the past towards their prophets and messengers, as well as the steadfastness, patience, and help of Allah to the prophets and messengers along with their followers, has been conveyed by Allah in Surah al-An'am/6.

With this verse, Allah also promises help and victory to the Messenger of Allah and those who believe. This is also affirmed by the word of Allah swt:

Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during this worldly life and on the Day when the witnesses will stand - (al-Mu'min/40: 51)

Allah swt says:

That He may reward those who believe and do righteous deeds out of His bounty. Indeed, He does not like the disbelievers. (ar-Rum/30: 45)

The verses above and the verses before it explain the conditions for the coming of Allah's help to those who believe, namely:

1.  Believe sincerely and wholeheartedly.

2.  Always uphold what is right and act justly.

3.  Always be steadfast and patient in any situation in facing Allah's trials.
text.35:
In this verse, Allah states to Prophet Muhammad that if the Prophet feels burdened by the disbelief of the polytheists who turn away from the religion of Allah and make various requests for them to believe, then the Prophet is welcome to seek a tunnel in the earth or a ladder to the sky to obtain other evidence to satisfy them. The Prophet certainly will not be able to, so do not be angry or sad because of their disobedience. The only one who will give them guidance is Allah, so entrust everything to Allah.

Indeed, the polytheists have long asked for such things, due to their disbelief, not to seek the truth. Because these requests were not fulfilled, their disbelief increased, as mentioned in Allah SWT's word:

"And they say, "We will not believe you until you break open for us from the ground a spring." (al-Isra'/17:90)

Allah SWT's word:

"Or you have a house of gold, or you ascend into the sky. And we will not believe in your ascension until you bring down to us a book we may read." (al-Isra'/17: 93)

Allah affirms, "You, O Muhammad, are a human being who has been appointed as a Messenger, therefore you cannot do something that exceeds human capabilities. The only one who is able to bring about such things is Allah, because Allah controls everything."

If Allah willed for them to receive guidance, believe, and acknowledge the message you convey, or to make them like angels, who are always submissive and obedient to Allah, or to make them all good people, with the same level and ability, the same customs and character, then that would be very easy for Allah. But Allah wills otherwise. Allah bestows upon them intellect, thought, will, and feelings, with which they can weigh and choose what is good, what is bad, what is right, what is wrong, and so on.

Allah regulates this universe with His Sunnah. Everything proceeds according to His Sunnah; no one is able to change, add to, subtract from, or replace His Sunnah. Therefore, O Muhammad, do not be like someone who does not know about His Sunnah, so that you aspire to something that is not in accordance with the Sunnah of Allah.
text.36:
This verse explains that only those who listen will respond to Allah's call. Then, in facing the Prophet's call and the message he conveyed, humanity is divided into two: people whose souls are alive and people whose souls are dead.

People whose souls are alive are those who use the intellect, thoughts, feelings, will, and choices that Allah has bestowed upon them. With these gifts, they can see, pay attention to, and evaluate everything presented to them. They take what is good and discard what is bad. Therefore, their hearts and minds are open to receiving Allah's guidance. They are like fertile soil. With just a little water, the soil will become fertile, able to grow plants easily and quickly.

Meanwhile, people whose souls are dead are those who refuse to use the intellect, thoughts, feelings, choices, and inner eye that Allah has bestowed upon them. Their hearts have been closed by envy. Therefore, they will not hear or pay attention to any explanation presented by the Prophet. Even if they could see and pay attention to the arguments and evidence presented by the Messenger, and their minds accepted it, all of it would be rejected and not accepted because of that envy. They are likened to barren land; no matter how much water is poured onto it, the land will not grow the plants that are planted.

This second group of people are the disbelievers whose disbelief has deepened, so there is no hope that they will believe and obey the Prophet's call. Therefore, Allah encourages Muhammad (peace be upon him) not to grieve over their attitude, and to surrender their situation to Allah. Allah will resurrect them from their graves on the Day of Judgment and will punish them as a reward for their disbelief.
text.37:
This verse further affirms the attitude of the polytheists who are very disbelieving towards the call of Prophet Muhammad and the verses of Allah. They demanded that proofs and explanations regarding the truth of Muhammad's prophethood be revealed to them, as had been revealed to the previous Messengers. They were not satisfied with the proofs and explanations contained in the Qur'an, even though the proofs and explanations contained in the Qur'an are of the highest value for those who are willing to use their reason, thought, and the eyes of their hearts. They continued to demand that proofs and explanations be revealed as had been revealed to previous peoples, but they did not want to think about and learn from the *sunnah* of Allah that applies to those who receive such proofs and explanations, and the consequences experienced by those previous peoples, namely that they were destroyed in this world and in the Hereafter they received a painful torment, because they remained in disbelief and did not pay attention to those proofs and explanations.

The polytheists of Mecca did not want to know how Allah's mercy was upon them, namely why Allah did not reveal proofs and explanations as were revealed to previous peoples, so that they would not be destroyed in this world, thus giving them the opportunity to repent and do good. But they did not want to be grateful for the blessings of Allah that had been revealed to them, but remained disbelieving and rebellious.

Indeed, Allah is Powerful to send down what they asked for, but Allah acts according to His will. He only sends down proofs and explanations; He does not send down proofs and explanations based on the requests and desires of the polytheists, especially if the request is solely to weaken and make things difficult for the Prophet.
text.38:
This verse states that Allah controls everything, His knowledge encompasses all existing creatures, and He regulates the universe. Everything that crawls on the surface of the earth, everything that flies in the air, everything that lives in the oceans, from the smallest to the largest, from the visible to the hidden, only He creates, develops, regulates, and maintains them.

Allah's creatures that live in this world are not limited to humans, but there are many kinds and varieties of other creatures. In fact, many are still unknown to humans. All of them submit and devote themselves to Allah, following His commands and stopping His prohibitions.

The meaning of the word *dabbah* in this verse is: All creatures created by Allah on earth. It is called "animals on earth" because animals on earth are the ones that are easily seen and noticed by humans.

In another verse, Allah mentions that besides on earth, there are also living creatures on other planets. Allah SWT says:

And among His signs is the creation of the heavens and the earth and what He has dispersed throughout them of creatures. And He, for gathering them when He wills, is competent. (ash-Shura/42: 29)

The existence of living creatures mentioned by Allah on other planets, as mentioned in this verse, is knowledge given by Allah to humans, and as material for thought and investigation.

This verse encourages believers to investigate all forms of life of Allah's creatures in this universe, to strengthen faith and increase obedience and submission to Allah the Almighty.

Allah states that in the Qur'an there are already the principles of religion, norms, laws, wisdoms, and guidance for the happiness of humans in this world and the hereafter, and the happiness of creatures in general.

According to Ibn 'Abbas, what is meant by "al-kitab" in this verse is "Ummul Kitab", namely Lauh Mahfudh. Because the meaning of this verse according to him is: everything has been written in Lauh Mahfudh. According to Ibn Kathir, there is not a single creature that Allah forgets in giving sustenance, as Allah SWT says:

And there is no creature on earth but that upon Allah is its provision, and He knows its resting place and its deposit. All is in a clear book (Lauh Mahfudh). (Hud/11: 6)

All creatures created by Allah, both in the heavens and on earth, will die and return to their owner, namely Allah. Then He will resurrect them and gather them to reward good deeds and punish bad deeds.
text.39:
The disbelievers who deny the verses of Allah that have been revealed to His messengers, which prove the power and oneness of Allah, as well as the truth of the message brought by Prophet Muhammad, are like the deaf, not listening to the call to truth, not heeding guidance to the right path. They are also like the mute, because they do not speak and convey the truth that they have known, and they have been immersed in darkness, namely the misguidance of worshiping idols, blindly following their ancestors, and ignorance in *tauhid* (Islamic monotheism). They will be put into hell.

Allah SWT (Subhanahu wa ta'ala - Glory to Him, the Most High) says:

And We have certainly created for Hell many of the jinn and mankind. They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. They are like livestock; rather, they are more astray. It is they who are the heedless. (al-A'raf/7: 179)

Those whom Allah wills to be misguided, then Allah allows them to take the path of misguidance, because they deny the verses of Allah and do not want to understand His guidance. Those whom Allah wills to receive *taufik* (divine guidance and enablement), then He makes them follow the straight path, the path of truth, because they pay attention to and understand the verses of Allah, then they practice them in accordance with the *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way/laws) that applies in this universe.

Allah SWT says:

By which Allah guides those who pursue His pleasure to the ways of peace and brings them out from darknesses into the light, by His permission, and guides them to a straight path. (al-Ma'idah/5: 16)
text.40:
This verse reminds the disbelievers about their attitude and condition when struck by severe trials from Allah or when the Day of Judgment arrives. They remember and call upon Allah, the One and Only, begging for His help to be spared from the severe trials they are experiencing. But when they have been spared from those severe trials, they return to associating partners with Allah. Therefore, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to ask the polytheists who deny the verses of Allah and associate partners with Him, "Tell me, O polytheists, if the punishment of Allah comes upon you as it befell previous nations, such as violent storms, great floods, lightning striking from the sky, and so on, will you ask for help and protection from idols and deities, which you think can help and protect you?"

Allah answers that question, saying, "No! But only Him will you call upon." Meaning: O polytheists, worshippers of idols, if you are struck by punishment, as befell previous people, then you will not ask for help and protection from anyone other than Allah to save you from that punishment.

With the question and answer above, it is as if Allah is depicting the character of the polytheists in particular and the character of humans in general, which is that humans in a state of happiness do not remember Allah, but when in a state of difficulty and hardship, they remember and worship Allah.

Allah swt says:

"And when they embark on a ship, they invoke Allah, sincere to Him in religion. But when He delivers them to the land, at once they associate others with Him." (al-'Ankabut/29: 65)

Allah swt also says:

"And when waves come over them like canopies, they supplicate Allah, sincere to Him in religion. But when He delivers them to the land, there are among them those who are moderate. And none rejects Our signs except everyone treacherous and ungrateful." (Luqman/31: 32)

The true fitrah (natural disposition) of humans is to believe in Allah, the One and Only, the Ruler and Owner of the entire universe. This fitrah in a person can develop and grow luxuriantly, and it can also be covered and its development stunted by the influence of the environment and so on.

Rasulullah saw said:

"There is no child born but is born upon fitrah (monotheism), then his parents make him a Jew, a Christian, or a Magian." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

In addition to the influence of parents and the influence of the environment, the influence of desires and wants can also affect or cover the fitrah of humans. Therefore, humans in times of happiness do not remember Allah. But when afflicted with misery, they remember Allah.

Allah SWT also says:

In addition to the influence of parents and the influence of the environment, the influence of desires and wishes can also affect or block the fitrah of humans. Therefore, humans in times of happiness do not remember Allah. But when afflicted with misery, they remember Allah.
text.42:
This verse affirms that Allah had indeed sent messengers to previous communities, calling people to embrace the religion of monotheism, worshipping Allah alone. The messengers delivered glad tidings and warnings from Allah, but the disbelievers denied them. Therefore, Allah inflicted upon them misery, calamities, and animosity among themselves, so that these trials would be a lesson for them, leading them to repent and follow the call of the messengers.

It has become the nature of most people that when they are afflicted with danger and misery, they remember Allah and seek His help. Because through these trials, their feelings become more refined, their character improves, their souls are trained to feel what others feel, love and compassion arise among fellow human beings, and they remember the Almighty and the True Helper. But there are also many among mankind for whom all kinds of trials and suffering are no longer effective; in fact, the trials only increase their denial, including those communities who lived during the time of the Prophet.
text.43:
Indeed, the best course of action for the previous communities was to follow the call of the messengers whom Allah sent to them, to submit and obey Allah when the punishment, calamity, or suffering was inflicted upon them, so that Allah might forgive their sins and bestow blessings and mercy upon them.

But their hearts had gone astray and were sealed shut, unable to receive any warnings or lessons conveyed to them. Satan instilled in their hearts and minds a sense of pleasure and joy in committing sins and *shirk*, and encouraged them to always engage in those reprehensible deeds.
text.44:
When those whose hearts are misguided and have been turned away by Satan forget all the warnings and threats of Allah, and their denial increases, then Allah tests them by bringing goodness and increasing their sustenance, making their bodies healthy, maintaining their safety, and opening the doors of pleasure, so that they forget that the blessings they receive and feel come from Allah. They assume that all of it is solely due to their own efforts. Therefore, they become more arrogant and conceited, ungrateful to Allah, and even use those blessings as a means to increase their power and greatness.

When those who disbelieve rejoice and are happy with the blessings that Allah has given them, and assume that what they have obtained is truly their right, then Allah inflicts punishment upon them suddenly, so that they grieve and despair of Allah's mercy.

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"When you see Allah giving a servant worldly pleasures that he likes, while he continues to disobey Him, then that is *istidraj* (allurement/gradual leading to destruction)." (Narrated by Ahmad, ath-Thabrani, and al-Baihaqi)

From this verse, it is understood that Allah's trials to humans can be in the form of misery and suffering, and also in the form of pleasure and luxury. Those who believe and are given the trial of misery and suffering are usually patient and steadfast, and draw closer to Allah and ask for His help. When they are given the trial of pleasure and luxury, they are grateful to Allah, remember the rights of the poor and needy around them, and spend some of their wealth in the way of Allah. They are certain that pleasure and luxury are only temporary, while the true and eternal pleasure and luxury are in the Hereafter.

Conversely, when those who disbelieve in Allah are given the trial of misery and suffering, they despair and become more disbelieving in Allah. When they are given pleasure and luxury, they say that everything they get, they obtain from their own efforts, without the help of anyone.

This verse indicates that humans in general are mostly steadfast and patient when given the trial of suffering and misery, but many are oblivious and become more disbelieving when given the trial of pleasure and luxury.
