This verse is a warning and lesson for those who believe, that all kinds of things that Allah brings to them, whether in the form of calamity and suffering or in the form of pleasure and luxury, are all trials for them, so that their faith becomes stronger, therefore they must be steadfast and patient in facing them.

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"How wonderful is the case of a believer; there is good for him in everything, and this is not the case with anyone except a believer. If joy befalls him, he is grateful and that is good for him; and if hardship befalls him, he is patient and that is good for him." (Narrated by Muslim from Shuhaib)
text.45:
This verse explains that those who disbelieve and deny the Messengers are destroyed because of their own actions; no one escapes that punishment. All praise is due to Allah who has destroyed the wrongdoers and who has bestowed His blessings and favors upon the believers.

This verse encourages Muslims to say the *hamdalah* "Alhamdulillahi rabbil alamin" (All praise is due to Allah, Lord of all the worlds) whenever they receive blessings, mercy, and help from Allah.
text.46:
Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to convey to the disbelievers that Allah is the One who gives mankind hearing, sight, and bestows hearts and feelings. What if Allah were to take away all that He has given them? Could they ask their gods or the objects of worship they worship besides Allah to restore it? Since Allah is the One who gives sight and hearing, all of it should be used to deepen faith.

With this verse, Allah proves that idols, objects of worship, and gods besides Allah that the polytheists worship have no power or ability whatsoever to fulfill or reject the requests of those who worship them. Statues and idols are inanimate objects made by humans to be used as objects of worship. The only One who can grant supplications, help, and protect them is Allah the Almighty; there is no other. Why do they still worship and ask for help from those idols?

Thus, Allah presents all kinds of evidence and explanations to the polytheists, making the objects of worship and idols they worship as proof and explanation for their error, but they still deny and do not believe.
text.47:
For those who deny the verses of Allah and reject the calls of the Messengers sent to them, punishment will come, sometimes suddenly, sometimes with signs that precede the punishment, sometimes it can be seen directly with the eyes and sometimes it cannot be seen directly, sometimes it comes during the day and sometimes it comes at night.

Therefore, let the polytheists remember that the wrongdoers and those who reject the calls of the Messengers will surely be afflicted with punishment, while those who follow the calls of the Messengers will be protected and saved from that punishment. Those who believe will not lose, and those who disbelieve will be punished.
text.48:
The purpose of Allah sending the Messengers is none other than to deliver good news, give warnings, convey the teachings of Allah that will become a guide for human life so that happiness is achieved in this world and the hereafter, and to warn humans not to associate partners with Allah in any way and not to create destruction on earth.

Whoever affirms and follows the Messengers who were sent to him, performs righteous deeds, then there is no fear for them that they will be afflicted with torment in this world, as was inflicted upon those who denied the Messengers in the past and denied Allah, nor with the torment of the hereafter that is promised for the disbelievers. They will not be sad and despairing when they meet Allah regarding something that has escaped them, because they are absolutely certain that everything that comes is from Allah. They are certain that Allah always protects and preserves them.

Allah swt says:

"The Greatest Terror will not grieve them, and the angels will receive them, (saying), "This is your Day which you have been promised." (al-Anbiya'/21: 103)

Those who follow the Messenger and perform righteous deeds will not be saddened if afflicted by calamities, such as the death of a child or a family member, the destruction of some or all of their wealth, or if they are afflicted with illness, and so on. They will be steadfast and patient in facing them, whatever happens will not affect their faith, deeds, morals, and ethics. Conversely, those who disbelieve will despair and be saddened by even a small trial from Allah.

Allah swt says:

"No disaster strikes upon the earth or among yourselves except that it is in a register before We bring it into being - indeed that, for Allah, is easy - So that you may not grieve over what has escaped you nor exult [in pride] over what He has given you. And Allah does not like everyone proud and boastful." (al-hadid/57: 22-23)
text.49: Those who deny the verses of Allah that the Messengers conveyed to them, sometimes they receive punishment in this world before receiving punishment in the Hereafter, and sometimes they only receive punishment in the Hereafter. They are punished only because of their own mistakes, namely because of their denial and wickedness (fasiq).
text.50:
The messengers who were sent were ordinary human beings, tasked with conveying Allah's religion to their respective communities. Unlike Prophet Muhammad, he was tasked with conveying Allah's religion to all of humanity. They brought good news to those who followed their call, with the reward of multiplied blessings from Allah, and gave warnings and threats to those who denied the message, with the recompense of a great torment.

These messengers were not like the messengers desired by the disbelievers, namely those who could perform miracles, possessing abilities beyond those of ordinary humans, such as having knowledge exceeding human knowledge; not being human, but like angels; or possessing power like the power of Allah, and so on.

In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to explain to the polytheists that he is a Messenger sent by Allah, that he is an ordinary human being, that he does not possess Allah's treasures, that he does not know the unseen, and that he is not an angel.

What is meant by "treasures" is a place to store goods, especially valuable items belonging to oneself or others entrusted to the person holding the treasure.

The disbelievers assumed that if Prophet Muhammad was truly a Messenger of Allah, then he would certainly be Allah's treasurer. Therefore, they asked Prophet Muhammad to give and distribute to them valuable items stored in the treasury and to utilize them.

The assumption of the disbelievers was very far from the truth, because Allah is the owner of the entire universe, as Allah swt says:

"To Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and whatever is within them, and He is over all things competent." (al-Ma'idah/5: 120)

In managing and regulating His possessions, Allah does not need anything, as Allah swt says:

"…And He is not burdened by their preservation. And He is the Most High, the Most Great." (al-Baqarah/2: 255)

Allah affirms that He is the owner of the treasures of the heavens and the earth, His word:

"But to Allah belongs the treasures of the heavens and the earth, but the hypocrites do not understand." (al-Munafiqun/63: 7)

The task of the Messenger is only to convey Allah's religion to mankind according to his ability as a human being. He cannot do something that humans cannot do, unless Allah wills it. Therefore, he cannot provide sustenance to his poor followers, cannot make his followers victorious in war solely because of his power, and he is unable to know whether someone has truly believed in him after being guided by him or to keep someone in disbelief.

Allah swt says:

"Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [responsibility for] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills…" (al-Baqarah/2: 272)

Allah swt says:

"Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of who are [rightly] guided." (al-Qasas/28: 56)

The Prophet saw can indeed provide guidance, but guidance in the sense of *irsyad* and *bayan* (direction and explanation), not guidance in the sense of *taufik* (divine enabling). Allah swt says:

"And indeed, [O Muhammad], you guide to a straight path." (asy-Syura/42: 52)

Therefore, if the disbelievers asked Muhammad saw for something strange, such as making rivers flow in the deserts of Arabia and having beautiful gardens there, causing the sky to fall in chunks to punish them, or showing them angels, of course Muhammad would not be able to fulfill it, and it would even be impossible for him to fulfill it.

Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to affirm to the disbelievers that he never said that he knew the unseen that humans do not know, because he was not given the ability to know it.

There are two kinds of unseen:

a. Absolute (*mutlak*) or essential (*hakiki*) unseen, which is not known by any creature, including angels. Only Allah knows it. This is the unseen referred to in the verse above.

Allah swt says:

"Say, "None in the heavens and earth knows the unseen except Allah, and they do not perceive when they will be resurrected." (an-Naml/27: 65)

If Allah wills, then He informs His Messengers of this kind of unseen, such as informing Prophet Musa of a man from the Children of Israel who killed his brother, after his murdered brother came back to life, after being struck with a part of the slaughtered cow. Another example is informing Prophet Isa that after him, Allah would send a messenger from the descendants of Ismail, and so on.

b. Relative (*nisbi*) unseen, which is not known by some creatures, but known by others.

The reasons why some creatures know it, and others do not, include:

1. The knowledge possessed. People who are knowledgeable are better able to know the reality of something according to their field of knowledge compared to people who are not knowledgeable.

2. Experience in doing a job, such as the movement of something indicating that there is a force moving it, and so on.

3. Intuition or conscience, about the existence or non-existence of something. This intuition or conscience is obtained by someone because of the purity of his soul, or because of the exercises he usually does for it. This non-essential unseen is not included in the unseen mentioned above, which only Allah knows.

Some *mufassirun* (Quran commentators) use the verse "wala aqulu lakum inni malak" as a reason to strengthen their opinion that angels are higher in rank than humans. But if it is carefully considered, this verse is not intended to explain who is more superior between angels and humans. This verse only explains who and what a messenger actually is.

As is known, according to the beliefs of the people of Jahiliyyah Arabia at that time, angels were creatures of Allah who were higher in rank than humans. Angels know the unseen that humans do not know. Some of them said that angels are the children of Allah. Therefore, they argued that prophets and messengers are not ordinary humans, at least equal in rank to angels. They asked Prophet Muhammad to show them the angels and that Allah should send angels to them.

To refute and provide explanations to the polytheists, it is as if Prophet Muhammad asked them to follow their opinion first by saying "wala aqulu lakum inni malak" (and I do not say to you that I am an angel).

Then Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to affirm to the polytheists that what he conveyed was nothing but revelation from Allah, not something fabricated by the Prophet.

Prophet Muhammad had been known since childhood as al-Amin, "the most trustworthy." He was commanded by Allah to convey whatever revelation he received. Allah had titled him as al-balagul mubin (the clear conveyor). But criticisms were also conveyed to him, such as the case of Abdullah bin Ummi Maktum.

Then Allah affirms that the blind and the seeing are not the same, those who receive guidance and those who do not receive guidance are not the same, the attributes of Allah and the attributes of humans are not the same, and likewise the attributes and tasks of angels and the attributes and tasks of the Messenger are not the same. Pay attention to such differences, so that it is clear which is true, which is wrong, which should be followed and which should be avoided. Only those who do not want to use their minds cannot see these differences.
text.51:
The reason for the revelation of this verse is narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Jarir, Ibn Abi Hatim, and ath-Thabrani from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, who said, "The leaders of the Quraysh passed by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), and near him were companions who were considered of low status by the Quraysh, such as Suhaib, Ammar, Khabab, and others. The leaders of the Quraysh said, "O Muhammad, are you willing for these of low status to be our replacements? Are they the ones whom Allah has favored among us? Are we to become their followers? So remove them from you, perhaps if they are removed, we will follow you." Then Allah revealed this verse.

In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to give warning and convey Allah's threat to those who deny his call, after in the previous verses Allah commanded him to convey the message. This is natural, because the person who is given warning and threat has received the call of the Messenger and his teachings, so that he can benefit from the teachings, in accordance with the word of Allah SWT:

"You can only warn those who fear their Lord unseen and establish prayer. And whoever purifies himself only does so for [the benefit of] his own soul. And to Allah is the [final] destination." (Fathir/35: 18)

The word of Allah SWT:

"You can only warn one who follows the message and fears the Most Merciful unseen. So give him good tidings of forgiveness and noble reward." (Yasin/36: 11)

Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to give warning to those who have believed, who have acknowledged the existence of the Hereafter, and the existence of a day on which people will face Allah to account for all their deeds that they have done in the world, and no one can help another, as mentioned in the word of Allah SWT:

"(It will be) on a Day when a soul will not possess for another [soul] anything, and the command, that Day, is [entirely] with Allah." (al-Infithar/82: 19)

Those who truly believe always strive to perfect their *taqwa* to Allah, always seek His pleasure, without depending on others such as *wali* and righteous people. They are convinced and believe that faith, good deeds, and purity of soul can free them from all of Allah's torment.

As for the disbelievers, they do not need to be given warning, because the warning and threat are of no benefit to them, they do not believe in the slightest that faith, good deeds, and purity of soul can free them from Allah's torment.
text.52:
Allah warns the Messenger that he should never ignore those who worship and call upon Allah morning and evening, solely seeking Allah's pleasure by purifying their obedience to Him, even if they are people from the lower strata of society.

They worship, do good deeds, and give charity solely for Allah's sake, not desiring praise from people, as mentioned in Allah's words:

(Saying), "We feed you only for the countenance of Allah. We wish not from you reward or gratitude." (al-Insan/76: 9)

Allah's words:

And not [conferring] upon anyone a favor for which a reward is expected. But only seeking the countenance of his Lord, Most High. And he is going to be satisfied. (al-Lail/92: 19-21)

Even if some of them are considered low in status in society, they are the most noble in the sight of Allah. Allah swt says:

Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted. (al-hujurat/49: 13)

The above verse and the reason for its revelation indicate to the Prophet Muhammad that the *sunnatullah* (Allah's way) has applied to him as it applied to previous messengers, namely that most of those who believed and followed their call early on were people who used their intellect, but they were poor or considered lowly by their society, while the leaders of society and the rich opposed and denied the messenger's call, as Allah swt says.

And We did not send a warner to a city except that its affluent said, "Indeed, we are disbelievers in that with which you were sent." And they said, "We are more [than you] in wealth and children, and we will not be punished." (Saba'/34: 34-35)

Allah swt says:

Said the eminent among his people who disbelieved, "We do not see you but as a man like ourselves, and we do not see you followed except by those who are the lowest of us [and] at first suggestion. And we do not see in you over us any merit; rather, we think you are liars." (Hud/11: 27)

Allah warns the Prophet Muhammad that he has no right to judge the actions of those who pray and worship Allah morning and evening, just as they have no right to judge the actions of the Messenger. The only One who has the right to judge everything is Allah because He is the Owner and Ruler of the universe. The believers are not slaves and are not messengers or employees of the Messenger; they are servants of Allah who are always seeking His pleasure, while the Messenger is the messenger of Allah who is tasked with conveying the revelation to mankind.

Allah swt says:

So remind, you are only a reminder. You are not over them a controller. (al-Gasyiyah/88: 21-22)

Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad should never drive away those who worship and humble themselves, morning or evening. If the Prophet saw did so, it would mean that he is among the wrongdoers, because the only One who has the right to judge and reward is Allah alone.
text.53:
The parable explained in the previous verse is a kind of trial and test from Allah to those who believe. This trial is intentionally given by Allah to test and strengthen the faith of someone who truly believes, is steadfast and patient in facing these trials. Conversely, those who lack or have no faith will certainly not be steadfast and patient in facing them.

These trials and tests are given by Allah in various forms. Sometimes the trial takes the form of differences that exist among humans; some are rich, some are poor, some are strong and some are weak, some are powerful and some are controlled, some oppress and some are oppressed, and so on. Likewise, some are ignorant and some are intelligent, some are healthy and some are sick, and so on.

Those who are weak in faith will feel humiliated by the words of the disbelievers, "Those who embrace Islam are only foolish people, poor people, and people from low castes." Or the words of the disbelievers, "Indeed, we are the ones loved by Allah because we are given abundant sustenance and high knowledge by Allah." And so on. Meanwhile, those who are strong in faith are not affected in the slightest by such words; in fact, their faith is strengthened by it.

Allah is the One who determines the giving and increase of blessings to His servant. The giving of these blessings is to test who is grateful and who is ungrateful. If humans are grateful, their blessings will be increased. But those who are ungrateful will be punished.

Allah SWT says:

"And [remember] when your Lord proclaimed, 'If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe.'" (Ibrahim/14: 7)
text.54:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad, and the believers to say "salam" to the believers they meet, or when they part from one another. The utterance of salam can be "salamun 'alaikum," sometimes "assalamu'alaikum," or "assalamu'alaikum warahmatullah wabarakatuh," and followed up by maintaining peace.

The word "salam" means "safe," "prosperous," or "peaceful." "As-Salam" is one of the names of Allah, which means that Allah is free from attributes that are not worthy of Him, such as weakness, poverty, being new, death, and so on.

The utterance of "salam" that Allah commands the believers to say in this verse, contains the understanding that Allah declares to those who have entered Islam, that they are safe and prosperous by entering Islam, because their sins have been forgiven, their lives and blood have been protected by the Muslims, and they have followed guidance that leads them to happiness in this world and the hereafter. Therefore, Muslims should not fight each other, let alone be hostile.

Some scholars of tafsir are of the opinion that what is meant by "salam" in this verse is the "salam" that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had to say to the believers who were considered lowly and poor by the Quraysh, who came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was talking to the Quraysh dignitaries. Do not drive them away, so as not to hurt their feelings. Even though they are poor, their position is higher in the sight of Allah, therefore say good words to them or tell them to wait until the conversation with the Quraysh dignitaries is finished. According to this group, their opinion is in accordance with the reason the verse was revealed.

To those who enter Islam, Allah promises to bestow His mercy upon them, as a grace from Him.

Among the mercies bestowed by Allah is that those who are not punished are those who:

1. Commit disobedience without knowing that the act is an act of disobedience.

2. Commit prohibitions unconsciously, due to extreme anger or because of the urge of lust. Then they repent, and regret the act, they promise not to repeat it, and make amends by doing good deeds, and eradicating the influence of the bad deed in their hearts, until their hearts and souls are cleansed, and they become closer to Allah.

From this verse, a basis can be taken in determining punishment that things that can eliminate, reduce or lighten the punishment of a person who will or has been sentenced, namely:

1. The mistake he made was done unconsciously, or the act was done without his will and choice.

2. His actions or behavior show that he has promised in his heart not to repeat the act, he has regretted committing the crime, and is doing good deeds.
text.55: The way of life for believers is to do good deeds. If they err, it is due to mistakes. As for the way of life for those who do not believe, it is to commit sins. Thus, Allah explains His verses to mankind with the utmost clarity so that the believers may know clearly which is the path of the righteous and which is the path of the sinful.
text.56:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to convey to the polytheists that he had been forbidden from worshipping anything other than Allah. In the Qur'an, this prohibition includes worshipping and seeking help from idols, worshipping and enslaving oneself to angels, to people or graves considered sacred, and so on. This prohibition is found in the Qur'an that Allah has revealed to him, accompanied by strong evidence and proofs that can increase conviction in the truth of Allah's prohibition.

It is also explained that what the polytheists worship are things that cannot provide benefit or harm in the slightest, cannot provide help to those who ask them, and are unable to avert any disaster that befalls their worshippers. They worship other than Allah solely following their desires and wishes, following the customs that were commonly practiced by their ancestors, without strong evidence or proofs. Therefore, the Prophet and the Muslims will not follow their invitation.

Prophet Muhammad was also commanded to convey that he and the Muslims would not follow their invitation. Because, if he followed their invitation, it would mean he was following something without a strong foundation and was misguided, and he would thus not be a Prophet.
text.57:
Allah commanded the Prophet (saw) to convey to the polytheists that he possessed proof of his prophethood, namely revelation. This revelation informed of life after death, but they requested its hastening, even though that was Allah's prerogative, and Allah is Most Truthful in the news He conveys (an-Nahl/16: 1).

The Prophet Muhammad and his followers did not follow their invitation, because the religion he conveyed was accompanied by strong foundations, arguments, and explanations, based on the guidance revealed by Allah contained within the Al-Qur'an. As for the polytheists, they invited the Prophet and the Muslims to follow their religion, but they did not present arguments and explanations that could strengthen the foundation of their beliefs, so that conviction would arise in the person they invited regarding the truth of their religion.

Among the reasons they denied and rejected the Al-Qur'an and the prophethood of Muhammad was because Allah did not grant their request that punishment be sent down upon them, as had been sent down upon the people of previous prophets, as proof of Muhammad's apostleship, as Allah (swt) explained in His word:

And (remember) when they (the polytheists) said, "O Allah, if this (Al-Qur'an) is indeed the truth from You, then rain down upon us stones from the sky or bring us a painful punishment." (al-Anfal/8: 32)

It is known that the One who establishes and determines all things is only Allah; there is none besides Him. He alone knows the wisdom behind the occurrence or non-occurrence of something in this universe. In determining the occurrence or non-occurrence of something, He has rules and laws. The occurrence of something is in accordance with His rules and laws, as Allah (swt) says:

¦ And with Him is the measure of everything. (ar-Ra'd/13: 8)

Allah explains that everything mentioned in the Al-Qur'an is true and will indeed occur, in accordance with His word:

And they urge you to hasten the punishment. But Allah will never fail in His promise. And indeed, a day with your Lord is like a thousand years of those which you count. (al-hajj/22: 47)

The word of Allah (swt):

For every nation is an appointed term. When their term comes, they will not have it delayed nor advanced an hour. (Yunus/10: 49)
text.58:
If the punishment requested by the disbelievers were in the hands of Muhammad, peace be upon him, they would surely have been destroyed, because they had denied the verses of Allah, opposed the Prophet's call, and hindered others from entering Islam.

Allah is All-Knowing of the wrongdoers and those whose faith can no longer be hoped for. He is All-Knowing of the punishment that is fitting to be given to them, and He will surely punish them according to the time He has decreed.
text.59:
This verse explains that the keys to opening the doors to knowing the unseen (ghaib) are only with Allah; no one else possesses them.

What is meant by the unseen (ghaib) is something whose true essence is unknown, such as the afterlife, paradise, and hell. Even though humans have been given much knowledge by Allah, that knowledge is only a little compared to Allah's knowledge. There is much that humans do not yet know.

Indeed, Allah created this universe with all its contents, equipped with rules and laws that govern it from its beginning to its end. These provisions will not change in the slightest. Then Allah taught humans some rules and provisions to convince them that Allah is the Creator of everything so that they would devote themselves to Him. Therefore, if there are humans who claim that they know the unseen (ghaib), then their knowledge is only speculation and conjecture, not reaching the true essence. They also do not know for certain the consequences and wisdom of an event. Belief in the unseen (ghaib) is one of the pillars of faith.

Among the unseen matters that are not known by humans are mentioned in Allah's words:

"Indeed, Allah [alone] has knowledge of the Hour. He sends down the rain and knows what is in the wombs. And no soul perceives what it will earn tomorrow, and no soul perceives in what land it will die. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted." (Luqman/31: 34)

Knowledge of the unseen (ghaib) is only known to someone if Allah teaches it to him, as in His words:

"[He is] Knower of the unseen, and He does not disclose His [knowledge of the] unseen to anyone. Except whom He has approved of messengers, and indeed, He assigns before each messenger and behind him observers." (al-Jinn/72: 26-27)

Among the unseen things that Allah taught or informed His prophets of are:

Prophet Isa (Jesus) was taught by Allah to know what someone eats and stores in their house, His words:

"...and I inform you of what you eat and what you store in your houses..." (ali 'Imran/3: 49)

Likewise, to Prophet Yusuf (Joseph), Allah SWT said:

"[Joseph said], "You will not receive food before I inform you of its interpretation. That is from what my Lord has taught me..." (Yusuf/12: 37)

Then Allah explains the vastness of His knowledge, namely, besides Him knowing the unseen (ghaib), He also knows more about the essence and conditions that can be reached by human senses. He knows everything on land and in the sea, from the smallest and finest to the largest, from the place and time a leaf falls, the condition of the finest object in the darkest night, whether it is wet or dry, all of it is in Allah's knowledge, written in Lauh Mahfudh (the Preserved Tablet).

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Allah existed and nothing else existed, and His Throne was upon the water, and He wrote in the Lauh Mahfudh everything, and He created the heavens and the earth." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from 'Imran bin husain)

From the hadith above, it is understood that everything that exists is not beyond Allah's knowledge.
text.60:
This verse explains Allah's power over His creation, namely that He is the One who causes them to sleep at night to rest and eliminate fatigue from striving during the day to earn a livelihood and struggle to uphold His religion. This process is unknown to humans.

In another verse, Allah explains the reality of sleep and the reality of death, which is His saying:

"Allah takes the souls at the time of their death, and those that do not die [He takes] during their sleep. Then He keeps those for whom He has decreed death and releases the others for a specified term. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought." (az-Zumar/39: 42)

Allah is also the One who awakens people during the day. He knows what humans will do during the day before they do it. Believers will fill all their waking hours with all kinds of deeds that are pleasing to Allah, because they are certain that life in this world is temporary, while true life is in the Hereafter. As for the disbelievers, they fill their lives with all kinds of things desired by their desires, because they doubt the Hereafter, and as if they have believed that life in this world is the real life.

By causing humans to sleep at night and awakening them during the day, and with the rotation of time, their lives come to an end. Then they are caused to die and return to Allah to have their good deeds that they have done and the sins they have committed weighed. They are informed of all the deeds that they have done during sleep at night and waking hours during the day in accordance with what Allah has commanded.
text.61:
This verse affirms Allah's power, maintenance, and supervision over His servants. He cannot be controlled in the slightest by His creatures, including the deities and idols worshipped by the polytheists, because those deities and idols are unable to hold power and unable to provide help; in fact, they themselves are given help.

From this verse, it is understood that humans should devote themselves to Allah, because all knowledge, power, freedom, ability to move, and creativity are gifts from Allah to them. He is able to add to or take away His blessings whenever He wills. At the moment He takes away all His blessings, then humans have no meaning whatsoever.

Allah also sends guardian angels to humans who guard them and record their actions at all times. Everything is recorded, and nothing is left out. Allah swt says:

And when the pages (of deeds) are spread open. (at-Takwir/81: 10)

Regarding guardian angels, it is mentioned in the word of Allah swt:

And indeed, [appointed] over you are keepers, Noble and recording, They know what you do. (al-Infithar/82: 10-12)

Indeed, for every human being, there are several angels who constantly guard him in shifts, and there are also those who record his deeds, namely Raqib and Atid, as Allah swt says:

For each one are successive [angels] before and behind him who protect him by the decree of Allah. (ar-Ra'd/13: 11)

The Prophet saw said:

The angels alternate in guarding you, angels of the night and angels of the day, they meet (change shifts) at the time of the Fajr prayer and the time of the Asr prayer. Then the angels who guarded you at night ascend to heaven, and the Lord asks them (while He knows better than them), "How did you leave My servants?" They replied, "We left them in a state of prayer, and we came to them in a state of prayer as well." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Actually, Allah does not need recording angels to record all human actions, because He is All-Knowing of everything. With the existence of recording angels who record all human actions, it is hoped that humans will be careful when they want to do something, whether that work is pleasing to Allah or not.

Thus, the guardian and recording angels guard, supervise, and record all human actions until the moment death comes to him. With the arrival of the angel of death taking the soul of man to carry out the command of Allah, the end of man's life arrives. Allah swt says:

Say, "The angel of death who has been entrusted with you will take you, then to your Lord you will be returned." (as-Sajdah/32: 11)
text.62:
This verse explains that those whose souls have been taken by the angel of death return to Allah to have their affairs judged, and Allah will give a decision based on His law with the utmost justice. He has the power to punish, and no one can change His decision. He is very quick in rendering judgment.

Indeed, all reckoning, recompense, and punishment in the Hereafter will be solely based on the deeds, actions, and conduct of humans during their lives in the world, whether they conform to the limits that Allah has determined or not.
text.63:
Allah commanded His Messenger to say to the polytheists, "Who can save and deliver you from the darkness of the land when you are lost, who is able to deliver you from the misery and suffering of life, who is able to deliver you from the darkness of the sea when you sail in its midst, then a hurricane comes with great waves, so that you no longer know the direction and purpose?" The only One who can save people from all darkness and misery is Allah, there is no other.

It is human nature that if they are in a state of difficulty and danger, they remember Allah, they surrender, submit and obey Him accompanied by prayer and asking for His help. Even in such a situation, they promise to remain surrendered to Allah and be grateful for His blessings if the difficulties and dangers are averted from them. But after the difficulties and dangers are averted, they forget the promises they have made, and they even become unjust people and associate partners with Allah.

Their condition is described in the word of Allah SWT:

"He is the One Who enables you to travel on land and sea until, when you are in ships and they sail with a favorable wind, rejoicing in it, there comes upon them a storm, and the waves surge upon them from every side, and they assume that they are overwhelmed. They cry out to Allah, sincerely offering Him their devotion, "If You save us from this, we will surely be among the thankful." But when He saves them, at once they transgress in the land without right..." (Yunus/10: 22-23)
text.64: Allah affirms that only He saves and delivers mankind from all kinds of hardship and suffering, not the objects of worship or idols they worship, because those objects of worship and idols are not capable of removing even the slightest hardship and suffering from them. But after being saved and delivered from danger, the disbelievers revert to associating partners with Allah.
text.65:
This verse is a stern warning to those who only remember Allah in times of suffering and hardship, then after that suffering and hardship disappear, they return to associating partners with Allah (shirk).

The warning is that Allah has the power to bring a punishment whose true nature is unknown to humans, perhaps from above or from below, perhaps from the right or from the left, perhaps in the form of a hurricane or a violent volcanic eruption, or to confuse people, so that they become divided into factions and groups that are always in conflict or they kill each other so that some of them feel the violence of others. Therefore, let the disbelievers remember that even though at one time Allah saved them from suffering and hardship, if they disbelieve again, Allah has the power to bring a calamity even greater than that.

According to Ibn 'Abbas, what is meant by "punishment from above you" is your leaders, and what is meant by "punishment from under your feet" is that which comes from slaves and common people.

The "punishment" referred to in this verse is all kinds of calamities that befall humans, such as wars, persecution, oppression, floods, volcanic eruptions, droughts, and so on.

Allah commands the Prophet and the Muslims to observe how Allah explains and brings forth signs of His power alternately, in various forms and ways, so that in this way it is easy to understand and believe, easy to know what is true and what is false.
text.66:
The disbelievers among whom Prophet Muhammad resided had denied the punishment, even though the punishment was true, as proven by the history of nations before Prophet Muhammad, and the history of the Muslim community itself. Some *mufassirin* (Quranic commentators) are of the opinion that what is meant in this verse is that they denied the Qur'an, even though the Qur'an is true, without the slightest doubt in it, and there will be no errors in it from the past until now and in the future.

"Say to those disbelievers, O Messenger, that you cannot control and protect them, nor are you the one who manages their affairs, and you also do not have the power to make them believers. But you are only a human being assigned by Allah to convey His religion to them."

This statement is further emphasized by the word of Allah SWT:

So remind [O Muhammad], you are only a reminder. You are not a dictator over them. (al-Ghashiyah/88: 21-22)

The word of Allah SWT:

We are most knowing of what they say, and you are not over them a tyrant. But remind by the Qur'an whoever fears My threat. (Qaf/50: 45)
text.67:
In this verse, Allah reaffirms that all the news contained in the Qur'an has a time for its occurrence. At that time, it will be known whether the news is true or false, and at that time, its accuracy will be known, as well as the wisdom behind the occurrence of that news.

These important pieces of news are in the form of promises and threats. Allah's promise for those who follow the call of the Messenger, good rewards for those who do righteous deeds, and a great punishment for those who deny the Messenger, all of this will be shown by Allah.

Allah SWT says:

"Say, "Have you considered: if the Qur'an is from Allah and you disbelieve in it, then who is more astray than one who is in extreme dissension?" We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves until it becomes clear to them that it is the truth. But is it not sufficient concerning your Lord that He is, over all things, a Witness?" (Fussilat/41: 52-53)
text.68:
This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad, if he sits with disbelievers and they mock the verses and religion of Allah, to immediately leave them unless they change their conversation to another topic. This action is carried out so that the disbelievers realize that their actions are disliked by Allah and the Muslims, or if the Prophet continues to sit with them, it means the Prophet seems to approve of their actions.

The Prophet Muhammad and his companions, as well as Muslims in every era, are commanded to leave those who mock the verses of the Qur'an. This includes all kinds of actions that aim to mock the religion of Allah, interpreting and explaining the verses of the Qur'an only to follow their desires.

If these verses are connected with the verses that command Muslims to fight those who oppose Islam, it seems as if these two verses are contradictory. This verse seems to tell Muslims to remain patient no matter what the disbelievers do to them. While other verses command to kill the disbelievers wherever they are found.

The answer is that these verses were revealed during the time when the Prophet Muhammad was still in Mecca, when the Muslims were still weak, at which time the Prophet's main task was to convey the teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism). At this time there was no command to fight and indeed there was no wisdom in being commanded to fight. After the Prophet was in Medina, and the condition of the Muslims had become strong, and there was a command to fight, then the attitude of allowing the actions of those who mock the religion of Allah is a reprehensible attitude, even it is commanded that Muslims retaliate against their actions.

Then Allah warns the Prophet Muhammad, that if he is made to forget by Satan about Allah's prohibition of sitting together with people who mock religion, then when he remembers, he should immediately stand up and leave them, do not sit with them.

What is meant by "the Prophet forgets" here is forgetting ordinary things, just as ordinary people also forget. But the Prophet never forgot the things that Allah commanded him to convey.

The *ahli tafsir* (Quranic commentators) agree that the Prophet Muhammad ever forgot, but not because of Satan's interference, as Allah SWT says:

¦ And remember your Lord when you forget¦ (al-Kahf/18: 24)

Prophet Adam once forgot, as Allah says:

¦ but he forgot, and We did not find in him determination. (thaha/20: 115)

Prophet Musa also forgot, Allah SWT says:

He (Moses) said, "Do not rebuke me for my forgetfulness and do not burden me with hardship in my matter." (al-Kahf/18: 73)

The Prophet Muhammad, once forgot during his prayer, then he said:

"I am but a human being like you, I forget as you forget, so if I forget, then remind me." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abdullah)

Allah affirms that Satan can only influence those who are weak in faith, while against those who are strong in faith, Satan cannot influence them and make them forget Allah.

Allah SWT says:

Indeed, there is for him no authority over those who have believed and rely upon their Lord. His authority is only over those who take him as an ally and those who through him associate others with Allah. (an-Nahl/16: 99-100)

Based on the above explanation, it can be concluded that Satan is not able to make a believing servant forget something, let alone make the Prophet forget something, because he cannot control Allah's believing servant. In this verse, it is mentioned that Satan makes the Prophet forget is only a habit in language, that all kinds of bad deeds are caused by the deeds of Satan, even if the one who does it is not Satan. If a believing servant who is strong in faith forgets, then his forgetting is only because of the influence of his own heart and soul, not because of the influence or interference of Satan.

Some *ulama* (Islamic scholars) establish laws based on this verse, as follows:

1. It is obligatory to distance oneself from people who are playing with the verses of Allah, or people who interpret the verses of Allah only to follow the desires of their *hawa nafsu* (whims and desires), if one is unable to rebuke them to stop doing that.

2. It is permissible to sit together to discuss something beneficial with disbelievers, as long as they do not mock the religion of Allah.
text.69: This verse affirms that believers who are pious to Allah are not responsible for the actions of polytheists who mock the verses of Allah, and they will not bear the sins of the polytheists. They are obligated to give a warning to the polytheists who act in this way, to no longer mock the verses of Allah.
text.70:
Allah commands Prophet Muhammad and the believers to sever ties with those who treat their religion as a plaything and a target of jest. They have been deceived by the pleasures of worldly life and have forgotten that true life is in the Hereafter. They do not purify themselves and their souls, nor do they improve their character as Allah has taught. They are negligent and forgetful of their meeting with Allah in the Hereafter, wasting precious time by filling their worldly lives with various actions that harm themselves.

Allah also commands the Messenger and the Muslims to warn them with the verses of the Qur'an, so that they are not plunged into Hell because of their own deeds. On that day, nothing can help, bring good, or ward off the evil and misery they experience except Allah. On that day, there will be no means to ransom oneself to escape the punishment of Allah. As Allah swt says:

"And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, nor will compensation be accepted from it, nor will any intercession benefit it, nor will they be aided." (al-Baqarah/2: 123)

This verse refutes the opinion that in the Hereafter there will be intercessors who can reject or alleviate punishment besides Allah, such as idols, people who are considered to have *karamah* (divine grace), and so on.

Allah affirms that those who mock the religion of Allah have forbidden themselves the reward and bounty of Allah in the Hereafter. Therefore, for them is a painful punishment; they are plunged into Hell as a result of their own deeds, and in Hell they drink boiling water because of their disbelief.
text.71:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad and his followers to say to those who invited him to follow their religion and worship idols together, that they should not seek help from anything other than Allah, such as worshipping stones or trees and other things that cannot provide benefit or ward off harm. Rather, he should only worship Allah alone, the One who has power, who gives benefit or harm, and who controls creation, who gives life and death.

People who think rationally can certainly distinguish between good and bad, and between right and wrong; indeed, devoting oneself to the Being whose benefit can be hoped for and whose punishment is feared is more noble and better than devoting oneself to something whose benefit cannot be hoped for. Devoting oneself to Allah is better than returning to the path of error and wallowing in polytheism.

In short, it can be said that worshipping other than Allah is not appropriate for the following reasons:

1. A person who thinks rationally will seek help from the Almighty Being, who can bring benefit and ward off harm.

2. They do not want to apostatize like their state before embracing Islam.

3. People who have received guidance from Allah and have been saved from the abyss of error cannot possibly be led astray again by anyone, as affirmed by Allah in His word:

And whoever Allah guides - for him there will be no misleader. Is not Allah Exalted in Might and Owner of Retribution? (az-Zumar/39: 37)

In this verse, it is depicted that those who apostatize after believing are like people affected by the whispers of Satan, or like people confused in achieving something that they themselves do not know how to achieve. They are in a state of hesitation, because they feel that they are at a crossroads. They have left the straight path and are taking a misguided path with no direction or purpose. In the midst of that confusion, they are depicted as if they are being called by their believing friends to return to the straight path, but they cannot fulfill that call because they have separated themselves. Their views and thoughts are already directed towards the whispers of Satan, so they can no longer hear the call. This depiction is in accordance with Allah's word:

...like the standing of one whom Satan has driven mad by his touch. (al-Baqarah/2: 275)

After that, Allah gives encouragement to Prophet Muhammad to always strive so that the polytheists can fulfill the Prophet's call to return to the straight path and avoid the misguided path, which confuses their minds.

Allah affirms that the true guidance is the guidance revealed by Allah, which is contained in His verses. In that guidance, there are proofs and explanations about His truth that contain no falsehood.

This call is different from the call proclaimed by those who follow their desires, who only follow in the footsteps of their ancestors. Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to say to them that the task entrusted to him is to surrender his soul and body solely to Allah, the Lord of the universe.
text.72:
Allah commands Prophet Muhammad and his followers to establish prayer regularly and perform it according to the provisions stipulated by Islamic law (Sharia). Allah also commands them to be pious (taqwa), which means guarding themselves from anything that could lead them astray from the religion of Allah and His Sharia, and protecting themselves from harm and corruption that endangers them.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns all of mankind that Allah will gather them on the Day of Judgment (Mahsyar). On that day, mankind will be driven to face their Lord, and all their deeds will be examined and rewarded accordingly. This warning is given so that they can think and feel that worshiping other than Allah, or fearing the power of other than Allah, or expecting help from other than Allah, is an incorrect action.
text.73:
Allah invites mankind to contemplate the creation of the universe so that their minds may be opened and they may believe that this universe, full of beauty, must have a Creator, namely Allah, Who created the heavens and the earth with all their inhabitants as proof of the truth, and also created the laws of nature that apply universally, sometimes containing wisdom and secrets that demonstrate the attributes of the Creator, His Oneness, and His unlimited power. The heavens and the earth and all that is in them were created by God harmoniously and orderly, nothing is in vain. Allah says:

"Our Lord! You have not created all of this without purpose." (ali 'Imran/3: 191)

Also His saying:

"We did not create the heavens and the earth and what is between them for amusement. We did not create them except with truth (haq)." (ad-Dukhan/44: 38-39)

Allah affirms that when creating the universe and establishing its laws, everything proceeds according to His will, without the slightest difficulty and without anything hindering or changing its laws. All events occur either obediently or by compulsion. That is why Allah affirms that when He created the heavens and the earth, He created them with truth, because all His commands are true and His creation is true, in accordance with His saying:

"Unquestionably, His is the creation and the command." (al-A'raf/7:54)

In addition, Allah also has the power to judge all mankind after they are resurrected from the graves and gathered on the Day of Judgment (yawm al-mahsyar). That is the power of Allah that cannot be matched by kings and rulers, no matter how vast their power; because even though kings have the power to make regulations and punish violators, they will be powerless on the Day of Resurrection, because at that time power will be solely in the hands of Allah.

Then Allah provides information about His power, to give understanding to all mankind that nothing is beyond His knowledge. Allah knows the entire universe, both what is visible and what is not, knowing actions done openly or secretly. He is very wise in creating everything harmoniously and in accordance with its function.

Therefore, it is not appropriate for intelligent people to enslave themselves to other than Allah, either directly or with the intention of making them intermediaries to draw closer to Him.
text.74:
Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to remind the polytheists of the story of their ancestor whom they revered, namely Prophet Ibrahim, so that they would follow the religion of their ancestor. Ibrahim invited people to embrace monotheism and stop the practice of shirk.

In this story, the conversation between Prophet Ibrahim and his father, Adzar, is revealed again. Prophet Ibrahim asked his father and his people whether it was appropriate for them to make idols, which they made themselves, as gods? Why did they not worship Allah who created them and controlled those idols? They should know that Allah is the only one worthy of worship. That is why Prophet Ibrahim affirmed that he truly knew that his father and his people had fallen into the valley of clear error, deviating far from the straight path.

Their actions were clearly misguided from the teachings of revelation and deviated from sound reason, because the idols were nothing more than carved statues made of stone, wood, or metal, and so on. Idols should be of a lower status than their sculptors. They should understand that idols are not God, but they are the ones who made them gods. Therefore, it is illogical for humans to worship fellow creatures when those creatures are unable to control the universe and everything in it, especially when what is being worshipped is a statue that cannot do anything.
text.75:
Allah provides an explanation of how He manifests the magnificence of His creation in the heavens and the earth, in their arrangement and the beauty of their colors. Allah showed Ibrahim the celestial bodies of various shapes and arrangements, revolving according to their respective regulations in an orderly manner. The earth, consisting of many layers containing minerals and ornaments, is very useful for the benefit of mankind.

All of this becomes evidence of Allah's power, which can be understood by humans if they are willing to think according to their fitrah (natural disposition).

Allah also explains the purpose of Ibrahim's introduction to the beauty of His creation, which is so that Ibrahim truly understands the natural laws that apply in this world, and Allah's power that controls those laws, so that it can be used as evidence when facing misguided polytheists, and become his guide to be among those who truly believe in the oneness of Allah.
text.76:
Allah explains the process of Ibrahim's recognition in detail. The first observation of Prophet Ibrahim was directed at the stars, namely when the stars appeared to shine and when they did not, he saw a star that shone the brightest. (That is the planet Jupiter (Musyatari) and some say the planet Venus (Zahrah) which was considered a god by star worshippers, a common practice among the ancient Greeks and Romans, while Ibrahim's people were also among its worshippers).

Then a question arose in his heart. "Is this my Lord?" This question was a denial of his people's assumption, so that they would be startled to pay attention to the reasons for the denial that would be put forward.

But, after the star sank and disappeared from his sight, the conviction arose that what sinks and disappears cannot be considered God.

This is Prophet Ibrahim's reason for refuting his people's belief that everything that undergoes change is not worthy of being considered God. Ibrahim's conclusion was the result of correct thought and observation and in accordance with fitrah (natural disposition). Anyone who makes similar observations will surely come to the same conclusion. Meanwhile, some mufassir (commentators), such as Ibn Kathir, say that Prophet Ibrahim's observation of the stars, moon, and sun was not the first observation, but rather a tactic of Prophet Ibrahim to invite his people not to worship something that rises and sets. But rather, they should worship the Eternal and Everlasting Being, namely Allah.
text.77:
In harmony with the previous verse, Allah also explains Prophet Ibrahim's observation of a celestial object that was brighter and appeared larger: the moon.

After Ibrahim saw the moon emerge from behind the horizon, with its bright and radiant light, an impression arose in his heart, leading him to say, "Is this my Lord?" Ibrahim's statement was a declaration that arose instinctively, just like the impression received by his people. The purpose of the question was actually a statement to deny the initial impression that deceived the eye and to refute the beliefs of his people, just like his statement in the previous verse. Repeating the news with a more definitive reality is to strengthen the previous statement. Then, after the moon set from the horizon and disappeared from observation, he posed a question so that the polytheists around him would know.

Ibrahim said, "Indeed, if my Lord had not guided me to the right path to know and believe in His Oneness, I would surely have been among the misguided, those who deviate from the truth and do not follow God's guidance, and worship gods other than Allah. They prefer to follow their desires rather than doing deeds that please Allah." This insinuation is a firm rebuke to his misguided people and at the same time a guidance for those who adhere to religion and revelation. This gradual insinuation aims to refute the opinions of his people. The first insinuation was gentle, then followed by the second, which was firm, to subtly refute the thoughts of his people so that they could break free from the shackles of their hearts to understand the true truth.
text.78:
Allah recounts a sharper allusion, namely Prophet Ibrahim's observation of the sun, the celestial body with the brightest light according to visual perception, which is the third sequence of Ibrahim's previous observations. After Ibrahim saw the sun rise on the horizon, he said: "This that is visible now is my Lord." This is greater than the star and the moon. However, after the sun set and disappeared from sight, he issued a warning: "O my people, indeed I am free from association with what you associate with Allah."

This allusion is the sharpest allusion to silence his people so that they would not offer any other reasons to deny the truth that Ibrahim had successfully proven.
text.79:
Allah recounts the non-involvement of Prophet Ibrahim from the polytheism of his people, and the continuation of that non-involvement by depicting Ibrahim's attitude and his pure monotheistic creed, namely that Ibrahim directs himself in his acts of worship to Allah who created the heavens and the earth.

He is also the One who created the bright celestial bodies in the vast expanse of space and who created all of mankind, including the sculptors of statues of various shapes.

Ibrahim inclined towards the religion of monotheism and declared that other religions are false, and he was not among the polytheists. He was one who surrendered himself to Allah alone. Allah's word:

And who is better in religion than one who submits his face [in Islam] to Allah while being a doer of good and follows the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth? (an-Nisa'/4: 125)

His word:

And whoever submits his face to Allah while he is a doer of good - then he has grasped the most trustworthy handhold. (Luqman/31: 22)
text.80:
Allah explains that the Prophet Ibrahim's invitation to the right path faced severe challenges from his people.

Ibrahim was refuted by his people when he conveyed the religion of monotheism because Prophet Ibrahim pointed out the errors of their religion, which involved worshipping idols and deifying stars.

The evidence presented by Ibrahim weakened, even invalidated, their creed, because their creed was based solely on blind adherence to their ancestors. That is why Ibrahim asked them why they rejected the religion of monotheism, even though Ibrahim had presented evidence of the truth of the religion of monotheism in accordance with Allah's guidance and Ibrahim's own conviction. Did they not know that the idols and stars they worshipped had shortcomings, while the Creator of the universe and its contents is Most Perfect? They should not worship a god that has imperfections. Then Prophet Ibrahim affirmed his stance against their refutation, that he was not afraid of the calamities and consequences of denying idols. Because their objects of worship are inanimate objects that cannot ward off harm nor provide benefit. Prophet Ibrahim's challenge was a response to the attitude of the polytheists who threatened Ibrahim with disaster for denying their objects of worship, as experienced by Prophet Hud when facing his people, Allah's word:

"We can say nothing but that some of our gods have seized you with evil." (Hud/11: 54)

How could their objects of worship inflict disaster upon him when those objects of worship cannot see and cannot hear, cannot be intermediaries and also cannot provide intercession, except if Allah wills the disaster to arise because of the idol. If that is indeed the case with the idols and stars, they would certainly have a negative influence on someone. But not because of the influence of the idols and stars, but solely because of Allah's power. All disasters that befall humans, from wherever they come, are only because of Allah's will and Knowledge.

At the end of this verse, Allah provides the reason for the exception contained in this verse, namely that Allah has vast knowledge, encompassing all that exists.
text.81:
Ibrahim affirmed that he was not afraid of their deities, but only feared Allah. Ibrahim's attitude drew their attention. Prophet Ibrahim said, why should he fear the deities they associated with Allah and made intermediaries, believing they could provide benefit and ward off harm? While they themselves were not afraid to associate Allah with their own created deities.

What should be feared is their disobedience to Allah and their false assumptions, namely considering statues and stars as gods. That is why Allah reproached their attitude. Allah explained to them that the religion that can be accepted is the religion that has strong reasons and acceptable evidence, especially since they only embraced religion by blindly following their ancestors. Such an act is not based on guidance and knowledge. Then they were faced with two choices, namely embracing the religion of monotheism or polytheism. Whereas they already knew that Allah has the power to create and destroy, to give life and to cause death, while the statues cannot provide any benefit or harm whatsoever. At the end of this verse, Allah commanded Prophet Ibrahim to ask them for an answer if they were able to answer it.
text.82:
Because they will not give an answer, Allah provides an explanation of who is entitled to the protection of the polytheists or the believers? The answer is, of course, those who believe with true faith and do not mix their faith with injustice, whether in creed or in worship, as done by the polytheists who assume that even though they worship idols or stars, they still believe in Allah Azza wa Jalla, because they worship those idols as a means to draw closer to Allah and as an intermediary to convey prayers to Him, as explained in Allah's word:

"We do not worship them except that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position." (az-Zumar/39: 3)

The injustice referred to in this verse is shirk, according to the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, and other hadith scholars from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, who said, "After this verse (al-Baqarah/2: 83) was revealed, the companions complained, saying, 'Who does not wrong himself?'" The Messenger of Allah replied, "It is not as you think," as in Allah's word:

"Indeed, association [with Him] is great injustice." (Luqman/31: 13)

Those who are entitled to protection in this verse are those who adhere to pure monotheism, unmixed with even a little shirk. They will receive protection from disasters, not only from disasters caused by statues and stars as the polytheists assume, but even more than that, they will receive protection from Allah's punishment and obtain a guarantee to receive rewards from Allah. They are the ones who receive guidance from Allah to the straight path.
text.83:
Allah affirms that the proofs of truth directed to Ibrahim were intended so that his people could use their minds to assess the truth of those proofs and accept them wholeheartedly, thus abandoning polytheism and turning to the religion of monotheism, which is indeed in accordance with human nature (fitrah).

To attract his people to return to the religion of monotheism and as a consolation for the struggles of Prophet Ibrahim, Allah promises that He will raise the degrees of His servants whom He wills, in the fields of knowledge and wisdom, or prudence. The degree obtained by Prophet Ibrahim is the ability to provide arguments (hujjah), the ability to lead, and to act wisely. All of these are degrees of perfection. In addition, he was also given the degree of prophethood and apostleship, which is the highest degree that humans can achieve. This is in accordance with Allah's saying:

"Those messengers - some of them We caused to exceed others. Among them were those whom Allah addressed [directly], and some of them He raised in degree." (al-Baqarah/2: 253)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is All-Wise in raising or lowering the degree of a person. He is also All-Knowing of the condition of those who deserve to receive that degree.
text.84:
Allah recounts to Prophet Muhammad and his followers that Allah bestowed a favor upon Prophet Ibrahim by raising up righteous descendants from him, namely Ishaq, as a continuation of his struggle, to uphold the religion of monotheism and destroy polytheism. Allah also raised up Ya'qub a.s., his grandson from the lineage of Ishaq a.s., as a successor to the struggles of the prophets and messengers. They were all submissive under the guidance of revelation, wisdom, and the knowledge of Allah to continue the establishment of the religion of monotheism.

Prophet Ishaq, the son of Ibrahim, is mentioned separately in this verse because of a noteworthy matter, which is included among the signs of Allah's power, namely that he was born after Prophet Ibrahim had reached old age, while Sarah, his wife, was also old and had not had children, and had no hope of giving birth, as explained in Allah's word:

"She said, "O wonder! Shall I bear a son when I am an old woman and this, my husband, is an old man? Indeed, this is an amazing thing!"" (Hud/11: 72)

This is a favor from Allah upon him for the strength of his faith, his perseverance in doing good deeds, and his steadfastness in facing various trials from Allah.

The guidance received by Ibrahim and his righteous descendants is the same as that which was given to Prophet Nuh previously, namely the guidance of the religion of monotheism.

The mention of Prophet Nuh here is so that people can understand that not all righteous servants of Allah will produce righteous sons, like Prophet Nuh. He was a righteous Prophet, but his son was misguided, drowned with the disbelievers because he refused to obey his father's command. This is the opposite of Prophet Ibrahim, whose father was an idol worshiper, but he himself was *hanif*, surrendering himself to Allah.

Among the other righteous descendants of Prophet Ibrahim mentioned in this verse are Daud, the son of Sulaiman, Ayyub, Yusuf, Musa, and Harun a.s. All of them, in addition to being given the degree of prophethood, were also given a high position. Daud and Sulaiman became kings and leaders with noble character. Ayyub and Yusuf, although not kings, had influence and were very close to the rulers. Yusuf himself became a minister who could control and overcome the difficulties of the people. While Musa and Harun, although they did not become kings, were given leadership and the ability to save their people from oppression.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that Allah will give a fitting reward to those who do good, namely those who always adhere to the guidance of Allah and hold fast to the truth.
text.85: Allah explains the various blessings that have been bestowed upon the righteous descendants of Prophet Ibrahim, who struggled to defend monotheism (tauhid) and destroy polytheism (kemusyrikan). They are Zakaria, Yahya, Isa, and Ilyas, who prioritized the afterlife over worldly life, so that they possessed the distinction of being His righteous servants. They are indeed worthy of being given such a designation, even though other prophets are also given the title of righteous (saleh) and are known for their goodness.
text.86:
Allah mentions again the descendants of Prophet Ibrahim who were given guidance and prophethood, namely Ismail, Ilyasa', Yunus and Luth. They were not only famous for their power or their asceticism, but they had advantages over their people because of the grace given by Allah. They defended monotheism and eradicated polytheism, and possessed noble character, making them worthy of being emulated by mankind.

Among them, some were sent in the same era, such as Prophet Luth, who was contemporary with Prophet Ibrahim, and Ismail who was contemporary with Ishaq. They all possessed virtue, although in reality the virtues possessed by each were different.
text.87:
This verse affirms that Allah bestows favor upon the family of Prophet Ibrahim, whether from his lineage, upwards, downwards, or sideways, or from his relatives.

This verse is a reaffirmation of the previous verses, namely the favors granted by Allah to Prophet Ibrahim's predecessors, namely Nuh and his descendants, namely Ishaq, Ya'qub, Daud, Sulaiman, Ayyub, Yunus, Musa, and Harun.

In addition, Allah also explains that He also bestows favor upon his family sideways, namely the children of Prophet Ibrahim's siblings who helped him in fighting for *tauhid*, who joined him in migrating to the land of Syam, namely Lut who was later sent to the land of Sodom. They were showered by Allah with the bounty of guidance, so that they could achieve invaluable glory and be guided to the straight path, the path that leads to happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.88:
Allah affirms that the guidance received by them is the guidance given by Allah to the prophets and messengers, as a *taufik* from Allah, which leads them to the right path and that which is pleasing to Him. Such guidance is given by Allah to His servants according to His will.

With that guidance, they defended *tauhid* and practiced His teachings sincerely, and eradicated the worship of idols and the veneration of stars. The guidance received is guidance that cannot be sought by humans. This guidance is only attained by those whom Allah wills.

At the end of this verse, Allah gives a warning to those who believe and walk under the shade of His guidance, that if they deviate from the religion of *tauhid* and worship other deities, then Allah will surely erase all the rewards from the deeds they have done.

Even though *tauhid* purifies the heart, if that purity of heart is tainted by *shirk*, no matter how small, then the purity of the heart is lost and the results of previous efforts vanish. This is in accordance with Allah's saying:

And it has already been revealed to you and to those before you that if you should associate [anything] with Allah, your work would surely become worthless, and you would surely be among the losers. (az-Zumar/39: 65)
text.89:
Allah affirms once again that the 18 prophets will receive Allah's guidance, which will serve as a guide in leading their respective communities.

Among them are those who were given a Book containing guidelines for life in leading their people to the right path and the ability to decide on matters that occurred among their people, such as Prophet Ibrahim, Musa, Isa, and Daud, as explained by Allah in His words:

(Ibrahim prayed), "My Lord, grant me wisdom and join me with the righteous." (ash-Syu'ara'/26: 83)

Allah's word:

"...then my Lord granted me wisdom and made me one of the messengers." (ash-Syu'ara'/26:21)

Allah's word:

"O David! Indeed, We have made you a successor (ruler) on earth, so judge between people with justice..." (shad/38: 26)

Among them are also those who were given wisdom and prophethood to guide mankind, namely those who were sent during the time of Prophet Musa or after him, before the arrival of Prophet Isa, such as Harun, Zakaria, and Yahya (peace be upon them).

Also among them are those who were given wisdom while still young, such as Yahya, Allah's word:

"O Yahya! Take the Book (Torah) with determination." And We gave him wisdom while he was a boy." (Maryam/19: 12)

More specifically, the mention of the names of the prophets in the context of Prophet Ibrahim is due to several reasons as described below:

The prophets mentioned in the previous verses, in addition to their status as prophets, were also given different privileges. They can be grouped into three categories:

The first group, which is mentioned, is Ibrahim's son who did not separate from him, namely Ishak, then his grandson, namely Ya'kub, because Ya'kub is the father of the descendants who carry the divine teachings. Then Prophet Nuh is inserted with the aim of reminding that no matter how high a person's degree, he should not forget his ancestors. Moreover, Prophet Nuh is the tenth grandfather of Prophet Ibrahim who is the most noble, because he was the first human to forbid idolatry.

In verse 84, the names of Prophet Daud, Sulaiman, Ayyub, Yusuf, Musa, and Harun are mentioned. Prophet Daud and Sulaiman are mentioned first because both built houses of worship (Masjidil Aqsa), as Prophet Ibrahim and Ismail built the Ka'bah. The mention of Prophet Ayyub and Yusuf in order is because both, although not rulers, have influence and are very close to the rulers. Both are combined because they have similarities, namely each being left by their families, although in the end both were able to meet again.

Prophet Musa and Harun are mentioned after Yusuf because Prophet Musa, assisted by Prophet Harun, succeeded in subduing the ruler of his time and was able to prosper his people.

After mentioning the prophets who became kings, then rulers who were not kings, and prophets who subdued rulers, then the prophets who were defeated by rulers are mentioned. The first order is Prophet Zakaria and Prophet Yahya, because both were killed by the rulers of their time. Then Prophet Isa and Prophet Ilyas are mentioned, because both were about to be killed, but were saved by Allah. Finally, the names of the prophets who are related to power are mentioned, namely Ismail, Ilyasa', Yunus, and Lut.

In short, it can be said that every prophet who was given a Book was certainly given wisdom or prudence as a weapon to decide cases in addition to being given *nubuwah*. However, not every Prophet was given the power to decide cases and given a Book.

Allah affirms that if the polytheists of Mecca and people who have the same characteristics deny the Book, wisdom, and prophethood given to the prophets, then Allah will hand over the degree of glory that was promised to other people who do not deny what was conveyed by the prophet.

What is meant by people who deny the virtue of the prophets are the disbelievers of Mecca, while what is meant by people who do not deny are the people of Medina.
text.90:
Allah explains to Prophet Muhammad and his followers that Prophet Ibrahim and his descendants received virtue and Allah's guidance to the straight path. Allah also commanded Prophet Muhammad to follow in their footsteps, uphold the religion of monotheism (tauhid), possess noble character, perform deeds pleasing to Allah, and adorn himself with excellent qualities, namely patience in carrying out his duties and steadfastness in facing the deception and challenges of his people.

Allah's word:

And all of the news of the messengers We relate to you, [O Muhammad], that thereby We may strengthen your heart. (Hud/11: 120)

Allah's word:

And already messengers were ridiculed before you, but they patiently endured ridicule and persecution until Our victory came to them. (al-An'am/6: 34)

The laws (syariat) that applied to the prophets before the arrival of Prophet Muhammad are also laws for the Muslim community, as long as they have not been revoked, altered, or replaced by the laws brought by Prophet Muhammad. What is eternal and has similarity is the foundation of the religion of monotheism (tauhid), which does not change throughout time, while the laws (syariat) of each prophet can change according to time, place, and circumstances, and according to the will of Allah.

Prophet Muhammad has the highest rank among the prophets and messengers, because in addition to being given prophethood, he was also given an eternal miracle, namely the Al-Qur'an, which confirms the books that were revealed before it, and because his laws (syariat) continue to apply until the end of time.

Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad that in conveying the revelation and upholding the truth, he should not expect any reward from his community, just as the previous prophets did not.

Prophet Muhammad, like the other prophets, did not expect compensation for his preaching. However, Prophet Muhammad hoped for affection in kinship, as affirmed in His word:

"I do not ask of you for it any payment - only affection among relatives." (asy-Syura/42: 23)

At the end of this verse, Allah provides confirmation that the Al-Qur'an was revealed for all of humanity. This verse indicates that Prophet Muhammad was not sent only for the people of Mecca or Medina, but was sent for all of humanity throughout the world to guide them to the right path and free them from misguidance.
text.91:
Allah explains that the Jews have deviated from the religion of monotheism and have not followed the teachings of their religion, and have betrayed it. These symptoms are evident in their attitude. They do not respect the majesty of Allah with the respect that should be given. They say that Allah did not send down a book to any human being. Their words are proof of their denial of the Qur'an. This means they do not acknowledge that Allah has the power to give guidance to humans other than themselves, for the benefit of humanity according to His will.

Their denial of the Qur'an does not arise from a clear mind, nor do they obtain its explanation from the books revealed before the Qur'an, but their denial is an inappropriate denial. Therefore, Allah commands Muhammad to explain to his people who deny, so that they remember that Allah sent down the Torah to Prophet Musa. With that book, Prophet Musa led his people to the religion of monotheism and avoided polytheism.

Allah reveals the evil deeds committed by the Children of Israel who have deviated from the Torah and the Gospel. They did not convey those books in their entirety; some parts were conveyed and some parts were hidden, causing differences of understanding among them. The reason is none other than that they were influenced by leaders who ordered them to indulge their desires. Even in resolving disputes, they revealed the laws contained in the Torah if the law was in accordance with their wishes. But if the law contradicted their will, the law was abandoned. Among the legal provisions they hid were the law of stoning (rajam), and news about the coming of Prophet Muhammad.
