O My servants, you sin by night and by day, and I forgive all sins, so ask Me for forgiveness and I will forgive you. O My servants, you will never be able to harm Me, so as to cause Me harm, nor will you ever be able to benefit Me, so as to cause Me benefit. O My servants, if the first of you and the last of you, mankind and jinn, were all of the most pious heart of any one man, that would not increase My dominion in anything. O My servants, if the first of you and the last of you, mankind and jinn, were all of the most wicked heart of any one man, that would not decrease My dominion in anything. O My servants, if the first of you and the last of you, mankind and jinn, were all to stand in one place and ask of Me, and I were to give everyone what he requested, that would not decrease what I possess any more than a needle decreases the sea when it is put into it (and taken out again). O My servants, I only keep account of your deeds for you, then I shall recompense you for them. So whoever finds good, let him praise Allah, and whoever finds other than that, let him blame no one but himself." (Narrated by Ahmad, Muslim, at-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah from Abu Dharr)

Such is a portion of Allah's wealth. As for His vast and limitless mercy and grace, it can be seen in the reality of the universe, His creation, and no one can deny it. In a hadith narrated from Abu Hurairah, it is explained that the Messenger of Allah saw said:

"Allah divided mercy into one hundred parts. He withheld ninety-nine parts with Him and sent down one part to earth. From that one part, all creatures show compassion to one another, so that a horse will lift its hoof for fear of stepping on its offspring." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Allah, the All-Sufficient, the Most Vast in His mercy, has forbidden injustice for Himself. If Allah acts by inflicting punishment on His disobedient servants, then His action does not contradict these attributes. So with this verse, Allah affirms to the enemies of the Prophet Muhammad that if Allah wills, He can certainly destroy them and replace them with another people that He created, just as He created them from another lineage. Allah's promise was proven by the destruction of the enemies of the Prophet Muhammad in the Battle of Badr, so that in the end there were no more polytheists in Mecca. They were replaced by people who believed and were pious, striving to exalt the word of Allah with their lives, bodies, and wealth. Although in defending the truth they were forced to take up arms and enter the battlefield, in every battle they became role models in their courteous attitude in treating their enemies, so that Western historians acknowledge that there is no nation that has not conquered another nation with full justice and compassion like the Arab nation that has embraced Islam.
text.134:
In this verse, Allah delivers His threat to the enemies of the Prophet. They have already received punishment in this world, and so it will be in the Hereafter. The punishment of the Hereafter that is threatened upon them is the blazing fire of Hell, which will surely befall them. No power can repel it, and they themselves cannot prevent or escape from it. The Day of Recompense will surely come, and all creatures will be resurrected. This is not difficult for Allah, the Almighty. Just as Allah has the power to create His creatures from nothing into existence, surely Allah also has the power to resurrect them, even if those creatures have died and become bones that have crumbled to dust. This proof is repeatedly mentioned in the Qur'an, including Allah's saying:

"And he presents for Us an example and forgets his [own] creation. He says, "Who will give life to bones while they are disintegrated?" Say, "He will give them life who produced them the first time; and He is, of all creation, Knowing." (Yasin/36: 78-79)
text.135:
Allah's threat against the polytheists who opposed Prophet Muhammad, as mentioned in verses 133 and 134, is followed by a challenge to them, instructing Prophet Muhammad to say to them, "Do whatever you intend to do according to your ability. I too will do the same; you will soon know which of us will attain success and victory. Know that the wrongdoers will not attain victory." Although this challenge contains a rather harsh meaning, the language remains refined, because Prophet Muhammad still refers to the enemies of Islam with the word "my people" (kaumku).

The meaning of "kaum" among the Arabs is very deep, almost the same as the meaning of "nation" in modern times. A person who loves his nation will feel obligated to defend it if they stray from the path of truth. In this statement, it is implied that Prophet Muhammad greatly hoped for their awareness and that they would return to the right path. This challenge also contains Allah's promise to the Muslims, that they will achieve a great victory over the misguided and unjust polytheists.

What happened later was in accordance with Allah's promise; the polytheists were continuously afflicted with defeat until the word of Allah was firmly established and polytheism was destroyed. This is proof that Allah's promise in the Hereafter will surely be fulfilled as well, because the promise in this world was also spoken before the event occurred, both related to future events. Allah's promise that He will help the believers throughout time, until the end of time, as long as they truly believe and are pious, truly implement His religious teachings in their entirety, and truly strive sincerely to uphold the word of Allah. As mentioned in His saying:

"O you who have believed, if you support Allah, He will support you and plant firmly your feet." (Muhammad/47: 7)
text.136:
This verse informs us that they divided what they obtained from crops and livestock into two parts. One part was for Allah, and the other part was for the idols they worshipped and revered. They said, "The first part is for Allah as our offering to draw closer to Him. The second part is for our idol deities, also to draw closer to Allah."

With such a division, they had become misguided, because sacrifice is an act of worship and a means of drawing closer to the one worshipped. Worshipping idols and statues is an act unacceptable to sound reason, because statues are inanimate objects that can do nothing; indeed, these statues were made by them.

This tradition was a religion fabricated by the leaders and prominent figures of the Arab nation at that time, to influence the common people so that they would continue to glorify and venerate the leaders as guardians and keepers of the idols and as those closest to them. Thus, they could rule over the common people, extorting them by ordering their people to be devoted by sacrificing possessions to the idols they considered to have power over their lives and to be able to bring blessings or disasters to whomever they wished.

The first part, which was intended for Allah, was used to feed guests, children, and the poor; while the second part, which was intended for the idols, was completely controlled by the guardians and keepers. But because they had been overcome by greed and avarice, the part intended for the idols could not be reduced or taken in the slightest to be combined with the part intended for Allah. Conversely, the part intended for Allah could be taken to be combined with the part for the idols, because the part for Allah was the right of the poor and those who desperately needed food, while the part for the idols was entirely the right of the rulers.

Such were the provisions they established, and how evil were those provisions. Besides the fact that the provisions constituted a seizure of the rights of the poor and those who desperately needed help, the aspects of the evil of their provisions are as follows:

a. They had violated the rights of Allah, because only Allah has the right to make provisions in matters of worship.

b. They had associated partners with Allah by associating idols with Him, whereas only Allah has the right to be worshipped, and to Him alone should all devotion be offered.

c. They gave precedence to the rights of idols over the rights of Allah.

d. The provisions were not based on sound reason, nor were they based on guidance or previous *sharia*s, but only on the desires of their own whims.

It is narrated by Ali bin Abi Talib and al-'Aufi that Ibn 'Abbas said about the *tafsir* of this verse, which means the following:

"Indeed, the enemies of Allah, when they cultivated or harvested crops, they divided it into two parts, namely, one part for Allah and another part for the idols. If the part set aside for Allah was scattered and then mixed with the part intended for the idols, then the scattered part was combined with the part for the idols. Furthermore, if the water intended for the plants of the idol's part flowed to the plants of Allah's part, then the plants of Allah's part were made into the plants of the idol's part. But if the water of the plants of Allah's part flowed to the plants of the idol's part, then the plants remained the part of the idols."
text.137:
In this verse, Allah explains the arbitrary actions of the leaders and religious figures of the polytheistic Meccans, who encouraged their followers to not hesitate in killing their own daughters for unclear and incomprehensible reasons. In fact, killing one's own daughter goes against human nature and contradicts the ideals of building a harmonious family. Consequently, it contradicts the building of a solid and strong community, because the strength and solidity of a community depends on the strength and solidity of the families that form it. Their encouragement was based on only three things:

First: Because of poverty or fear of being afflicted by poverty. This is explained by Allah in His words:

"And do not kill your children for fear of poverty. We provide for them and for you." (al-An'am/6: 151)

In another of His verses:

"And do not kill your children for fear of poverty. We provide for them and for you. Indeed, their killing is ever a great sin." (al-Isra'/17: 31)

Second: Because of fear of shame later on. They killed their daughters by burying them alive, because these children, when they grew up, might commit vile and reprehensible acts, or be seized as captives and enslaved, or marry men who were not their equals or were of a lower status than their fathers.

In this regard, Allah says:

"And when one of them is given good tidings of the birth of a female, his face becomes dark, and he suppresses (his rage). He hides himself from the people because of the ill of which he has been informed. Should he keep it in humiliation or bury it in the ground? Unquestionably, evil is what they decide." (an-Nahl/16: 58-59)

Third: Because they made vows to idols, that they would sacrifice their children to draw closer to those idols. Or for other reasons, for example, their custom that if they had a certain number of children, they would sacrifice one of them, as Abdul Muththalib, the grandfather of the Prophet Muhammad, once did when he vowed to sacrifice Abdullah, the father of the Prophet Muhammad, if he was given ten children. Thus were the encouragements of the polytheists that corrupted their nature and instincts as humans who have feelings of love and affection for children; this noble trait was reversed into cruelty. They did not hesitate to kill their own flesh and blood. Thus, they deceived their people so that they could no longer distinguish between good and bad, and which religious rules should actually be followed and implemented. If Allah had willed, Allah could have prevented them from those destructive acts and they would not have done them. Therefore, Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to let them make destructive rules as they pleased, because in doing so they would become weak and lose confidence in themselves.
text.138:
In this verse, Allah explains the decrees and regulations made by their leaders, which they established without relying on sound reason, Allah's guidance, or Allah's religion, namely:

1.  They took a portion of the produce of their crops and animals to be offered to idols and their objects of worship as sacrifices. This specific portion could not be touched except for the benefit of the idols, could not be given to anyone, and could not be eaten by men.

2.  They forbade certain types of animals such as *bahirah*, *sa'ibah*, *wasilah*, and *ham*. Their actions were refuted by Allah in His saying:

   "Allah has not appointed [such innovations as] *bahirah* or *sa'ibah* or *wasilah* or *ham*. But those who disbelieve invent falsehood about Allah, and most of them do not reason." (al-Ma'idah/5: 103)

3.  When they performed the Hajj pilgrimage or recited the *talbiah* according to their customs, they were not allowed to ride those animals or burden them with their belongings.

4.  When slaughtering animals, they did not mention the name of Allah, but instead mentioned the names of their idols and objects of worship.

Such were some of the decrees they made themselves according to their desires regarding crops and livestock, but they claimed that these regulations were from Allah. This was a lie against Allah, and they would surely receive punishment from Him. The Prophet Muhammad was commanded by Allah to rebuke them for forbidding and permitting things as they pleased and fabricating lies against Allah:

Say, "Have you seen what Allah has sent down to you of provision of which you have made [some] lawful and [some] unlawful?" Say, "Has Allah permitted you [to do so], or do you invent [something] about Allah?" (Yunus/10: 59)
text.139: In this verse, Allah also mentions the arbitrariness of the polytheists in forbidding and permitting things according to their will and the desires of their passions, namely regarding; the bahirah and sa'ibah animals. They allowed men to drink their milk but forbade it for women. If the animal gave birth to a male offspring, then the offspring could be eaten by men and was forbidden for women. If the offspring was born dead, then only then was the offspring permitted for both men and women. If the animal gave birth to a female offspring, then this offspring was allowed to live until it gave birth. They did this according to their own desires, fabricating falsehoods against Allah, so Allah threatens them with a fitting recompense and that Allah is All-Knowing of all the deeds of His servants and All-Wise.
text.140:
In this verse, Allah affirms that those who kill their children for unclear and untrue reasons as mentioned in verse 137, and those who forbid sustenance that Allah has bestowed upon them as mentioned in verses 138 and 139, are indeed losers, misguided, and do not follow the guidance given to them.

Killing a child is a foolish and very detrimental act, and it is the act of a person who no longer knows what is bad and what is good, who does not know profit and loss, because a child is a blessing and a gift from Allah that is priceless. The child will later maintain the continuation of life, who will become the strength and pride for the mother, father, and family, and even become a strength for the community and the country. If he is nurtured and educated well, he will surely become a good family member, and a useful member of society. Therefore, every mother and father is given by Allah the instinct to love, cherish, care for, and protect them. Mothers and fathers do not hesitate to sacrifice their own interests to defend and maintain the safety of their children. Sometimes they are even willing to die to save their children when they are in danger. If someone considers killing their child better than letting them live, because of fear of things that are not certain to happen, such as fear of poverty or fear of being ashamed, it means that they have denied Allah's great blessings and gifts and opposed their own instincts and nature. Such a person has certainly been deceived by Satan and blinded by irresponsible leaders and religious figures who only care about their position and status. People who accept teachings and regulations made up by misguided leaders, without thinking about whether the regulations are based on truth, can be accepted by a healthy mind, or whether the regulations are indeed based on religion, especially if the regulations only lead to losses or deny Allah's blessings, then such people deserve to be called misguided, people who do not receive guidance from Allah.

Al-Bukhari narrated that Ibn 'Abbas said, "If you want to know how foolish the Arab polytheists were, read verse 130 onwards from Surah al-An'am, up to verse 140."

Indeed, there are some traditions of Muslims that are the same as the traditions of pre-Islamic Arab ignorance (jahiliyah), some are improved, replaced, or reduced. According to history, this is because some Arabs preserved some teachings from the Prophet Ibrahim. But because of the long period of *fatroh* or emptiness, many deviations occurred from the original. So Islamic teachings return to good and true traditions in accordance with the original teachings of the Prophet Ibrahim, such as the Hajj rituals inherited from the Prophet Ibrahim.
text.141:
With this verse, Allah affirms that He is the One who created gardens, both those with trellises and those without. He is the One who created date palms and other trees whose fruits vary in shape, color, and taste. This should attract the attention of His servants and make them believe, be grateful, and be pious to Him. With date palms alone, they have obtained various benefits. They can eat the ripe but still fresh fruit, which is sweet in taste, and they can also dry it so that it can be stored for a long time and can be taken anywhere on a journey and does not need to be cooked like other foods.

Its seeds can be used as camel food. The trunk, leaves, fronds, and fibers can be utilized. Compared to trees in Indonesia, the date palm is like the coconut tree. Allah also bestows olive and pomegranate trees, some of which are similar in shape but different in taste. Allah allows His servants to enjoy the produce of various trees and plants as a gift from Allah. Therefore, His servants have no right whatsoever to prohibit what He has bestowed. Because Allah is the Creator, Allah is the Giver, then Allah alone has the right to prohibit or permit it. If any of His servants prohibit it, then he has considered himself equal in status to Allah, and those who obey him have associated partners with Allah, and this is undoubtedly *shirk*. The meaning of prohibiting food here is making it forbidden to eat, so if it is eaten, it is certainly sinful. As for prohibiting food for health reasons, prohibited by a doctor or for other reasons that are harmful, it is not included in *shirk*, because we are commanded by Allah to stay away from danger.

Then Allah commands to give a portion of the crop at harvest time to the poor, relatives, and orphans, to be grateful for Allah's blessings that have been bestowed upon mankind. Ibn Mundhir, Abu Syaikh, and Ibn Mardawaih narrated from Abi Sa'id al-Khudri that the Messenger of Allah (saw) interpreted Allah's words: (al-An'am/6: 141) with, "give the right of the poor from what falls from the stalk." Meaning, it falls when harvested.

In this regard, Mujahid said, "If you are harvesting and poor people come, then strike the stalks of the fruit you are harvesting and give them what falls from the stalks; if you have separated the seeds from the stalks, then give them some of it. If you have winnowed, cleaned, and collected it and it is known how much the value of the harvest is, then pay the *zakat*."

Maimun bin Mihran and Zaid bin al-A'sham narrated that the residents of Medina, when they harvested dates, brought the date stalks to the mosque, then they placed them there, then the poor came, then they struck the date stalks and gave them the dates that fell from the stalks. According to Sa'id bin Jubair, this was before the command of *zakat* was revealed. The Arabs always gave a portion of their crops for animal feed, charity to orphans and the poor. This custom was preserved by Islam when it enacted mandatory *zakat* (in the second year of Hijriah where *zakat* on agricultural products must be given or issued immediately after they are harvested, without being postponed).

Furthermore, Allah forbids eating excessively, because it is very dangerous to health and can cause various diseases that may endanger life. Allah, the Most Merciful to His servants, does not like His servants who are excessive.
text.142:
With this verse, Allah explains that He created livestock for His servants, some of which are large and have long legs, whose meat can be eaten, and can also be used as vehicles to carry them to their destinations, and can also transport their necessities and merchandise from one place to another. There are also animals that are small in body and short in legs, such as sheep and rabbits, to be eaten for their meat, their wool woven into clothing, and their skin taken to be made into mats or footwear, and so on.

Thus, it can be understood how Allah's love for His servants is manifested in providing all of humanity's needs with plants and animals, even making everything in the heavens and on earth for the benefit of His creatures, as mentioned in His word:

"Do you not see that Allah has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth and has completed His favors upon you, [both] outwardly and inwardly? But of the people is he who disputes about Allah without knowledge or guidance or an illuminating Book [of Scripture]." (Luqman/31: 20)

Then Allah commands His servants to eat of the sustenance He has bestowed upon them, but never to follow in the footsteps of Satan, whether from among the jinn or from among mankind. The leaders and guardians of idols act arbitrarily by fabricating rules and arbitrarily legalizing and prohibiting Allah's blessings bestowed upon His servants, without any guidance or command from the Lord. Indeed, Satan is the most obvious enemy of mankind, whose job is to mislead Allah's servants on the face of the earth.
text.143: Then, in this verse, it is explained in detail that Allah created eight animals in pairs, one pair consisting of ewes and rams, and the other pair consisting of female goats and male goats. Allah commanded His Messenger to say to the polytheists, as a sharp criticism containing mockery and reproach, "Which of these pairs of animals did Allah forbid? Did Allah forbid only the two males? Or the offspring carried by the ewes and female goats? Try to present evidence and explanation from the Book of Allah or explanation from His prophets that Allah forbade such a thing, if you are truthful people and not fabricating that decree and saying falsely that it is His explanation."
text.144:
Similarly, Allah has created pairs of male and female camels, and He has also created pairs of male and female cattle. Allah commands His Messenger to also ask the polytheists, "Which did Allah forbid, the male camel or cattle, or only the female, or the offspring carried by the female camel or cattle?" Of course, the polytheists will not be able to answer these questions that refute all their arguments and explanations.

They have forbidden some of the animals that Allah has permitted to be eaten, with untrue reasons and by lying against Allah. So, to invalidate their reasons and expose their lies, these questions are presented.

If they forbid only the males among these four types of animals, then all male animals, sheep, goats, camels, and cattle would be forbidden to eat. If what they forbid is only the females, then all females of these four types of animals would also be forbidden to eat. And if all the offspring of these four types of animals are forbidden, then what else is allowed to be eaten, because all animals that will be born later are offspring of the females.

In short, none of these four types of animals are forbidden by Allah. So, the matter of forbidding some of these animals is only the doing of the polytheists.

Then, with even sharper words, Allah commands His Messenger to ask them, "Have you witnessed yourselves that Allah commanded you to forbid these animals?"

Surely they will not be able to answer this question, because they forbid some of these animals only because they follow the devils and their leaders, or because they found their fathers and ancestors forbidding them, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"And when they commit an immorality, they say, "We found our fathers doing it, and Allah has ordered us to do it." Say, "Indeed, Allah does not order immorality." (al-A'raf/7: 28)

At the end of this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to say to them, "Why do you say that Allah has decreed something, when you yourselves know it is not from Allah?" After it is proven that they cannot answer the question and cannot present concrete evidence to justify their attitude and actions, and it turns out that they are only making up rules to permit and forbid something, and even that they have lied against Allah by saying that these decrees are from Allah, then Allah affirms that they are a zalim people, and lie against Allah to mislead people from the right path. As a result of their deliberately committing misguidance and misleading people, Allah will not guide them, and later in the Hereafter they will receive a fitting reward in the form of a very painful torment in Hell.
text.145:
In this verse, Allah commands the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to say to the polytheists who have fabricated their own rules and lied against Allah, and to say to other people that he does not find, in the revelation revealed to him, anything forbidden by Allah except for four types:

1.  Animals that die without being slaughtered according to the rules of Islamic law, including animals that die without being slaughtered, animals that die by strangulation, being struck, falling, and so on.

2.  Blood that flows or comes out of the body of a slaughtered animal or due to injury, and so on. This does not include blood that does not flow, such as the liver, spleen, and residual blood that adheres to the meat. This provision is mentioned, among other things, in a hadith:

Translation:

"Two kinds of carrion are lawful for us: carrion of fish and carrion of locusts. And two kinds of blood are lawful: the liver and the spleen." (Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Majah from Ibn 'Umar)

3.  Pork and all parts of its body, including its fur, skin, bones, milk, and fat.

4.  Animals that are slaughtered without mentioning the name of Allah, such as being slaughtered by mentioning the name of idols or other deities besides Allah.

A person who is forced to eat these foods because he is very hungry and there is no other food available, while he does not desire it and does not transgress the limits, is allowed to eat it only to relieve his hunger and protect himself from death.

Apart from the foods forbidden above, there are many kinds of animals in the hadith that are forbidden to eat, as found in the hadith narrated from Ibn Abi Shaybah and al-Bukhari from Ibn 'Umar that he said:

"The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade eating the meat of domestic donkeys during the Battle of Khaybar." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ibn 'Umar)

Also mentioned in the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim:

"The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade eating all wild animals with fangs and all birds with claws." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.146:
This verse also explains the foods that were forbidden only for the Jewish people, namely all animals that do not have cloven hooves. This means animals whose toes are never separated from one another, such as: camels, ducks, geese, and so on. The fat of cows and the fat of goats were also forbidden to them, except for that which is attached to the back or the large stomach and intestines, or the fat that is mixed with bones.

All the foods mentioned above were forbidden only to the Jewish people as a punishment for their disobedience, not because the food is inherently haram (forbidden) like the haram nature of pork and carrion. It was not the Sharia of Prophet Muhammad that forbade these foods to them, but all of this was haram according to their own Sharia. The Prophet only narrated it through revelation from Allah (Al-Qur'an).

Thus, it can be said that the Al-Qur'an is not the work of Muhammad, but a revelation from Allah conveyed to him. Because Prophet Muhammad himself would not have been able to know such things, as he was illiterate, while the polytheists of Mecca also did not know such things. Then Allah emphasizes that the prohibition of these foods for the Jewish people was as a punishment for their disobedience. Allah affirms that He is the Most Truthful in all His news and actions.
text.147:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad, if the disbelievers deny the truth he explains regarding lawful and unlawful foods, both for Muslims and those specifically forbidden for the Jews, then the Prophet (peace be upon him) should respond by saying that such is the decree of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, whose mercy is vast and who is All-Wise, and who does not hesitate to inflict His punishment upon the rebellious.

According to Mujahid and as-Suddy, this verse is addressed to the Jews, while some commentators believe it is addressed to the polytheists of Mecca, because Surah al-An'am is a Meccan surah. According to the first opinion, the meaning of this verse is as follows:

If the Jews deny you, O Muhammad, because they deny that the law revealed to them prohibited certain foods as a reward and punishment for their disobedience, then say to them that although Allah is Vast in Mercy and Most Compassionate towards His servants, this does not contradict His wisdom, because He, as the All-Powerful, All-Wise, and All-Just, will still inflict His punishment and retribution upon the unjust and disobedient. Inflicting punishment upon those who deny and rebel can be considered an act of compassion, because in doing so, the wrongdoer will realize his mistake and return to the truth. And it may also serve as a lesson for anyone so that they do not commit injustice like those who have been afflicted by Allah's punishment.

According to the second opinion, where this verse is addressed to the polytheists of Mecca, the meaning is as follows:

If the polytheists deny you regarding their error in prohibiting and permitting things, say to them that your Lord is Most Compassionate and Vast in Mercy, therefore He does not hesitate to inflict His punishment upon you in this world for that error and mistake. So do not be deceived because it is only a temporary postponement, not because He will not punish you. This is a severe threat to them if they continue to rebel and continue to fabricate lies against Allah by prohibiting what Allah has permitted, but hope is still given to them that they will be forgiven with His mercy and compassion if they stop that rebellion, repent, and believe in Him and His Messenger. Thus, they will be happy in this world by enjoying what He has permitted, and they will also be happy in the Hereafter by being saved from entering Hell and entering Paradise that He has prepared for those who believe.
text.148:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists will say to the Prophet Muhammad that if Allah had willed, they would not have associated partners with Him, would not have glorified and worshipped idols and other objects of worship that were worshipped by their ancestors, and if Allah had willed, they would not have forbidden the meat of certain animals, claiming that all these actions and deeds were the will of Allah, so that they could draw closer to Him. Allah willed that they forbid *shaibah* and *bahirah*, and Allah approved of the decrees they established. But Allah is free from all these accusations.

This is mentioned in Allah's saying:

"And those who associate others with Allah say, "If Allah had willed, we would not have worshipped anything other than Him, neither we nor our fathers, nor would we have forbidden anything without [order from] Him." Thus did those before them. So is there upon the messengers except [the duty of] clear notification?" (an-Nahl/16: 35)

These various statements of the polytheists are refuted by Allah by explaining that the nations before them who associated partners with Allah, denied His Messenger, and forbade things without His permission, were afflicted with Allah's punishment and destroyed as a reward for their disbelief and denial. If what they did was pleasing to Allah, then He would not have punished and destroyed them. Then Allah challenges them by commanding the Prophet Muhammad to say to them, "Do you, O polytheists, have knowledge about the punishments that you have decreed, which you can teach us? If there is indeed such knowledge, then present it so that we can consider it and compare it with the verses revealed to us or with the laws of the prophets before us." Of course, they cannot answer this challenge, because what they say is only their own fabrication, not based on knowledge of the laws of previous nations. Therefore, Allah emphatically labels them as people who follow only assumptions and conjectures and lie against Allah.
text.149:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to affirm to the polytheists who base their actions and decisions on conjecture, not on knowledge and the laws of the previous prophets, that Allah is the One who possesses knowledge, proof (hujjah), and strong foundations. He is the One who has the right to guide to the truth, which must be followed obediently by His believing and pious servants. Whoever among His servants is obedient to Him and follows the guidance He gives, will surely become a righteous and happy servant. But if any of His servants rebels, denies those guidances, and even dares to equate himself with Allah, then woe to him in this world and the hereafter. Everything is up to man whether he will choose the straight path that leads to happiness by following the guidance of his Lord or the path of error that leads to misery by denying that guidance and following his desires.

This is the path that Allah has ordained for all mankind and jinn. If Allah willed, He could have made you like angels who are always obedient to their Lord according to their nature, as explained in His word:

"They do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded." (at-Tahrim/66: 6)

It has become Allah's sunnah and decree that man must use his intellect to choose which path he takes. If he chooses the right path, he will be happy, and if he chooses the wrong and misleading path, he will be miserable. Such is the sunnatullah, and no one can change it.
text.150:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to challenge the polytheists to bring forth witnesses who dare to claim that Allah has forbidden certain livestock, such as *saibah* and *bahirah*. Surely, they will not be able to present these witnesses because it is impossible for someone to face Allah except in the afterlife, so that they can witness with their own eyes whether it is true that Allah has forbidden those livestock to them, or whether they are merely fabricating that decree according to their own desires. This challenge refutes all the arguments they put forward, and surely they will not be able to answer it.

If they were to present witnesses, which would certainly be false witnesses, then Allah forbids Prophet Muhammad from validating their testimony. In fact, Allah commands the Prophet to reject it firmly, because they are a people who have associated partners with Allah and do not hesitate to fabricate lies against Allah, let alone against Prophet Muhammad. In addition, Allah forbids the Prophet from following the desires of those who deny the verses revealed to him, do not believe in the Hereafter, and always associate partners with Allah through idols and other objects of worship. The Prophet is commanded to be firm towards the polytheists, and even towards all those who deviate from the path of Allah. Being lenient towards them, let alone compromising with them, will lead to clear misguidance, in accordance with Allah's word:

And if you obey most of those upon the earth, they will mislead you from the way of Allah. They follow not except assumption, and they are not but falsifying. (al-An'am/6: 116)
text.151:
At the beginning of this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to say to the polytheists who establish laws according to their desires that he will recite the revelation that Allah will send down to him. This revelation contains several provisions regarding things that are forbidden to them. These legal provisions come from Allah, so these provisions must be obeyed, because He alone has the right to determine legal provisions through revelation conveyed by the angel to His Messenger, who was indeed sent to convey legal provisions to mankind.

The legal provisions conveyed by the Messenger to the polytheists contain 10 very important core teachings that are the essence of Islam and all religions revealed by Allah to the world. Five of these ten provisions are found in this verse, four are found in the following verse (152), and one provision is found in the verse after that (153).

The scholars call these ten core teachings "al-Washaya al-'Asyr" (the ten commandments), of which five are mentioned in verse 151:

(1) Do not associate partners with Allah,

(2) Be good to both parents (mother and father),

(3) Do not kill children because of poverty,

(4) Do not approach (commit) evil deeds, whether openly or secretly,

(5) Do not kill a soul that Allah has forbidden to kill.

As for the prohibition against associating partners with Allah, it is the first and most absolute principle, whether by word or belief. Such as believing that God has partners, or by actions such as worshiping idols or other objects of worship.

After Allah commands humans to believe in Tawhid and not associate partners with Him, Allah commands humans to be good to their parents. This order clearly explains how important it is to be good to both parents, even if they are wrong or tell their children to associate partners with God, the child must still be good to them in this world and must politely refuse the parents' command or invitation to associate partners with God, as Allah says:

"But if they endeavor to make you associate with Me that of which you have no knowledge, do not obey them but accompany them in [this] world with appropriate kindness." (Luqman/31: 15)

In a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abdullah bin Mas'ud. He conveyed a hadith which means as follows:

"I asked the Messenger of Allah about the most virtuous deed?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Praying on time," what else after that? He replied, "Being good to both parents," what else after that? He replied, "Jihad in the path of Allah." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

What is meant by being good to both parents is respecting them, both with words and with actions full of love and affection, not because of fear or compulsion. This respect is obligatory, in addition to the child's obligation to provide for his parents who are unable to do so, according to the child's ability.

The command to be good to parents is followed by a prohibition for parents to kill their children because of the poverty that befalls them, because God will provide sustenance for them and their children.

Allah says:

"And do not kill your children for fear of poverty. We provide for them and for you. Indeed, their killing is ever a great sin." (al-Isra'/17: 31)

The prohibition against killing children in this verse is different from the prohibition against killing children in another verse (in Surah al-Isra' verse 31). In verse 151 of Surah al-An'am, the prohibition against killing children is because of fear of poverty that is being suffered (befalling). In this verse, it is explained that Allah will provide sustenance to parents who provide for their children, and the word means that Allah will provide sustenance to them (your children).

Meanwhile, in Surah al-Isra', Allah explains in the verse meaning "We will provide sustenance for them (children)" and the word means "Allah will provide sustenance for you (parents)." Prioritizing children in the provision of sustenance shows Allah's great concern for children, as a result of parents' fear of having children because they are afraid of becoming poor.

In this verse, Allah forbids approaching evil deeds, let alone doing them, whether in the form of actions, such as adultery, or accusing someone of adultery, whether the act is done openly or secretly.

It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas in interpreting this verse, that in the Jahiliyyah era people did not consider it evil to commit adultery secretly, but they considered it evil if it was done openly. So with this verse, Allah forbids adultery openly or secretly. Another opinion says that what is meant by visible (open) deeds are all deeds with body parts, while hidden deeds are deeds of the heart, such as arrogance, envy, and so on.

In this verse, Allah also forbids killing a soul without a just cause according to God's teachings. The Messenger of Allah said:

"It is not permissible to kill a Muslim soul, except for one of three things, namely: because of apostasy (a Muslim who reverts to being a disbeliever), zina, muhsan (zina of a person who has been married) and killing a human being without a just cause." (Narrated by Abu Daud).

Likewise, disbelievers who have a peace treaty with the Muslims must not be killed or disturbed, according to the words of the Messenger of Allah:

"They have rights as we (Muslims) have rights and have obligations as we (Muslims) have obligations." (Narrated by At-Tirmidhi)

After explaining five of these very important core teachings, Allah concludes this verse with an affirmation which means: That is what your Lord has commanded you, so that you understand its purpose, not like your actions of legalizing and forbidding something according to your desires.
text.152:
In verse 151, five of the ten "al-Washaya al-'Asyr" were mentioned, while in this verse 152, five or four commandments are mentioned (according to some *mufassirin*), with the remainder (the tenth) found in verse 153. These commandments are:

(6) Do not approach the property of an orphan, except in a way that is best.

(7/8) The obligation to give full measure and weight.

(9) Be just in speech, even if it concerns a relative.

(10) Fulfill the covenant of Allah.

As for the prohibition of approaching the property of an orphan, it means that no one is allowed to approach, use, or benefit from the property of an orphan, whether from the guardian or from another party, unless the approach is aimed at preserving and developing the orphan's property. Only when the orphan reaches adulthood should the property be handed over to him. Regarding age, the scholars state around 15-18 years old or by looking at the child's situation and condition, considering that maturity is not only based on age but on emotional maturity and responsibility so that he can maintain and develop his wealth and not be extravagant or squander his inheritance.

Regarding the obligation to give full measure and weight, this command is repeatedly mentioned in several surahs in the Al-Qur'an in various ways, forms, and connections with various issues, including Allah's words:

"And give full measure when you measure, and weigh with a straight balance. That is best [in this world] and best in its result." (al-Isra'/17: 35)

The Lord's command to give full measure and weight is only according to the ability that is usually carried out in this matter, because the Lord does not burden His servants except according to their ability. What is important is that there is no element or intention of deception. What is meant by the obligation to speak justly, even if it concerns a relative, is every word, especially in giving testimony and legal decisions. And this is very important for every development, especially in the field of morals and social affairs, without distinguishing other people from relatives. This has also been explained in Allah's words:

"Allah has promised those who believe and do righteous deeds [that] for them is forgiveness and great reward." (al-Fath/48: 29)

As for what is meant by the covenant of Allah, it is all promises, both to the Lord, such as Allah's words:

"Did I not enjoin upon you, O children of Adam, that you not worship Satan - [for] indeed, he is to you a clear enemy?" (Yasin/36: 60)

Another of Allah's words:

"And those who fulfill their promise when they promise." (al-Baqarah/2: 177)

This verse ends with the expression "that you may be reminded," because all the commands or prohibitions mentioned in this verse are generally known and carried out by the people of Arab Jahiliyah, and they are even proud of having these commendable qualities. So this verse reminds them not to forget, or so that they remind each other of the importance of carrying out Allah's commands.
text.153:
This verse explains that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was commanded to explain to his people that the Qur'an invites to the right path, urging them to follow the teachings of the Qur'an for the benefit of their lives, because the Qur'an is a guide and direction from Allah to obtain happiness in this world and the hereafter that is pleasing to Him. This is the straight path, follow it, and do not follow other paths that will lead you astray from the path of Allah.

In Sunan Ahmad, an-Nasa'i, Abu Syaikh and al-Hakim from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, it is narrated in a hadith which means: I and some other companions were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, then the Messenger of Allah drew a straight line with his hand and said, "This is the straight path of Allah," then he drew several more lines from the right and left of the first line and said, "These are misguided paths." At each end of those paths is a devil inviting people to take them, then the Messenger of Allah recited this verse (al-An'am/6: 152).

The scholars of tafsir say that being divided in the religion of Islam, due to differences of opinion and schools of thought (mazhab), is forbidden by Allah, because it weakens their unity and is very dangerous to the religion itself. Then this verse 153 ends with an encouragement to be pious (takwa) because it is through piety that happiness in this world and the hereafter that is pleasing to Allah can be achieved.
text.154: In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to say to the Jews that Allah has given the Book to Moses, which is the Torah, to perfect His favor upon those who do good, and to explain all laws, and as guidance and mercy for the Children of Israel (the people of Prophet Moses), so that they may believe that they will return to their Lord after death.
text.155: This verse further explains the attributes and position of the Qur'an, which encompasses all kinds of guidance and Sharia laws needed by all of mankind and jinn, to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. The Torah, which Allah revealed to Prophet Musa, is full of Sharia teachings and guidance that were only needed by the Children of Israel to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter, while the Qur'an, which was revealed to Prophet Muhammad, contains more guidance and a wider scope than the Torah. Therefore, follow its guidance and carry out all the commands and prohibitions within it, so that you may be given mercy, and you may be given guidance in this world.
text.156: This verse explains the wisdom behind the revelation of the Al-Qur'an, which is as guidance to monotheize Allah by purifying the soul from the impurities of shirk and distancing oneself from immoral acts and other evils. It also ensures that the Arabs, who always opposed the Al-Qur'an, will no longer be able to say on the Day of Judgement that the books of Allah were only revealed to two groups (Jews and Christians) before us, and that we did not pay attention to what was in the book revealed to them, because its language is different from our language, and most of us are ummi (illiterate) and we were not commanded to follow the contents of those books.
text.157:
The beginning of this verse is a continuation of verse 156, explaining the reasons for the revelation of the Qur'an so that the polytheists of Mecca would not say, "If only a book had been sent down to us as was sent down to the two groups (Jews and Christians) before us, and we were commanded or forbidden to follow its contents and our mistakes were explained, surely we would have been better guided than the Jews and Christians, because we are more intelligent and more diligent in carrying out these laws of Allah." Such words were always spoken by the people of pre-Islamic Arabia, as narrated by Allah in the Qur'an, including in Surah Fathir/35 verse 42. But those who said such things, after guidance or a warning came as they requested, did not heed it; instead, they increased in denial and strayed. Therefore, in this verse, Allah corners them with the statement, "If what you say is true, then indeed there has come to you a book from your Lord that brings the truth with complete explanations and with strong arguments, about aqidah (creed), ibadah (worship), muamalah (transactions), fadhilah (virtues), akhlak (morals), and the laws of sharia necessary to regulate the relationship between humans and the Creator and the relationship between humans with each other, so that if humans obey it, they will live in peace and security, happy in this world and the hereafter."

After Allah explains how great the guidance brought by the Qur'an is, Allah warns of the consequences of denying the Qur'an with His words in the form of a question, "... then who is more unjust than one who denies the verses of Allah and turns away from them?..."

Furthermore, the end of this verse affirms that Allah will give repeated punishment to those who turn away from His verses and distort their meaning.

Those who disbelieved and avert [others] from the way of Allah - We will increase them in punishment over [their] punishment for what corruption they were causing. (an-Nahl/16: 88)
text.158:
In brief, the verse explains the attitude of the polytheists, which is that they will not believe, even by challenging, requesting, or waiting for one of three things: First, the arrival of angels to take their souls as they suggested to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. Second, the coming of Allah's punishment according to their request to hasten the coming of the punishment that the Qur'an calls a threat to them. Third, the coming of the signs of the Day of Judgment. Because all these requests only show continued disobedience, at the end of this verse Allah warns them with a threat, "Say, [O Muhammad], to them: Wait, for indeed, we are waiting [with you]." This is explained in Allah's saying:

Those to whom We have given the Book recite it with its true recital. They [are the ones who] believe in it. And whoever disbelieves in it - it is they who are the losers. (al-Baqarah/2: 121)
text.159:

2.  Nationalistic fanaticism (ethnic lineage), because every nation and ethnic lineage (race) is not pleased to be ruled by another.

3.  Fanaticism of schools of thought and opinions regarding the fundamentals of religion and its branches.

4.  Religious fatwas according to personal thoughts and tastes only. Therefore, many people dare to give fatwas in Islam, even though they are not yet able to derive a ruling from the Al-Qur'an and hadith.

5.  Efforts and deception to create division from groups of enemies of Islam, so that many *hadith maudhu'* (fabricated hadith) are due to them who can influence the *ummah* (Islamic leaders) using them as arguments for the Islamic religion.
text.160:
In this verse, it is clearly explained that whoever does good deeds, Allah will reward them on the Day of Judgment with ten times the reward for their deeds. Whoever commits evil will only be recompensed with the equivalent of their evil, because Allah will not wrong them in the slightest or cause them any loss. What is meant by those who do good deeds here are the believers, because the good deeds of the disbelievers before entering Islam will not benefit them in the Hereafter, as explained in Allah's word:

That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whomever He wills of His servants. But if they had associated others with Allah, then worthless for them would have been what they were doing. (al-An'am/6: 88)

The meaning of the expression "a reward ten times as great" here does not include what Allah has promised with rewards that are far greater and multiplied to those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah up to 700 times.

If you lend to Allah a good loan, He will multiply it for you and forgive you. And Allah is Most Appreciative and Forbearing. (at-Tagabun/64: 17)

In the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad, many are found about the rewards for good deeds and evil deeds, even explaining the reward for those who have not yet done a good deed but only have the intention or determination to do it. This is mentioned in a hadith qudsi narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah, who narrated the following:

Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Allah said, 'If My servant intends to do a good deed and does not do it, then write for him one good deed. And if he does it, then write for him ten to seven hundred times the reward of a good deed. And if My servant intends to do an evil deed, do not write it (do not record it) as a sin before he does it. And if he does it, record for him one sin (evil).'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Allah said to His angels, 'If My servant intends to do an evil deed, do not write it (do not record it) as a sin before he does it. And if he does it, record for him one sin (evil). And if he leaves it (does not do it) for My sake (because of Allah), then write for him one good deed. And if he intends to do a good deed and does not do it, then write for him one good deed. And if he does it, then write for him up to seven hundred times the reward of a good deed.'"
text.161: In this verse, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) receives the command to say to his people and all of humanity, "Indeed, I have been guided by my Lord through His revelation to the straight path to attain happiness in this life and the hereafter." That is the religion of Ibrahim, not other religions that contain shirk, which people falsely associate with him, because Ibrahim was not among the polytheists. This verse simultaneously refutes the belief of the Arabs of Mecca that the angels are the daughters of Allah, and refutes the Jews who say that Uzair is the son of Allah, and the Christians who say that Isa is the son of Allah. Each of them claims that the religion they follow is the religion of Ibrahim, even though they have deviated from the religion of Ibrahim.
text.162:
In this verse, Prophet Muhammad is commanded to say that indeed his prayer, his worship, and all the work he does, his life and his death, are solely for Allah, Lord of the universe, who has no partners. That is what he was commanded. The Messenger is the first to surrender to Allah in following and obeying all His commands and prohibitions. These two verses contain Allah's teachings to Muhammad, which must be conveyed to his people, on how a Muslim should live his life in this world. All acts of prayer and other worship must be carried out diligently and wholeheartedly for Allah, sincerely without expecting anything in return. A Muslim must believe in the power and will of Allah, who has no partners. Allah determines a person's life and death. Therefore, a Muslim need not fear death in striving in the path of Allah and need not fear losing his position in conveying the Islamic da'wah, *amar ma'ruf nahi munkar*. This verse is always recited in prayer after *takbiratul ihram* as the *doa iftitah* except the word: is replaced with (164). In this verse, there is a command to Prophet Muhammad to say to his people, why would he seek another Allah by associating partners with Him in worship, praying for his life's needs so that He would help him or protect him from hardship and danger? Glory be to Allah from that association. He is the Lord of all things, He is the Creator of the universe. Furthermore, in this verse it is explained that all human actions will be accounted for by himself, and the one who commits sin will bear his own sin, because the sin of one person will not be borne by another. Each receives the reward for his good deeds and bears the sin of his bad deeds. This is repeatedly mentioned in the Qur'an.

Allah says:

(Namely) that no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another, and that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives. (an-Najm/53: 38-39)

This verse provides sufficient guidance and a high-quality and practical way of life, because in addition to having to do good deeds and work, every deed that is done must also be carefully and thoroughly considered. Because the work or deed has a very large influence in bringing a person's fate of good fortune and ruin, both in this world and in the hereafter. In the hereafter, the disputes of mankind in religion will be resolved.

text.165:
If we return to examine the surah of the Al-Qur'an in its entirety, we will be able to conclude that life and existence have been illuminated with the light of guidance from all directions, because within it are explained matters of *akidah* or belief and its proofs. The Messenger has conveyed Allah's commands through revelation to refute the disbelievers who are defiant, regarding the resurrection of the Day of Judgment and *al-jaza'* (the recompense of deeds), about the relationship between humans and their Creator, the relationship between humans and fellow humans, especially in doing good to both parents, about conflicts in religion, deeds, and others.

From the historical reality throughout time, it is proven that humans remain humans, in the past and now, there is always hostility even among siblings and fellow humans. Therefore, the connection and wisdom in the final verse can also be felt, "And it is He who has made you successors upon the earth and has raised some of you above others in degrees [of rank] that He may try you through what He has given you. Indeed, your Lord is swift in penalty; but indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful." This verse seems to say, indeed, your Lord who created everything, He is the one who made you rulers on this earth and He raised the degrees of some of you above others, both in position and wealth, as well as intelligence and others, because He wants to test you with what He has given you. Indeed, your Lord is swift in punishment and indeed, He is Forgiving to those who truly seek forgiveness from Him and Merciful to His believing servants.

This verse affirms that Allah is the one who made humans rulers on earth to manage the lives of their people, and He is also the one who raised the degrees of some of them above others. All of that is according to *sunatullah* to test each of them on how they respond to Allah's blessings that the Lord has given them. They will receive recompense from that test, both in this world and in the hereafter. Rulers are tested for their justice and honesty, the rich are tested on how they spend their wealth, the poor and the afflicted are tested for their patience. Therefore, humans should not be envious and jealous of God's gifts to someone, because all of that is from Allah and all of His gifts are a test for everyone.
